{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18768,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pseudopanax lessonii prefers moderate watering throughout the growing season. Ensure the soil is well-drained, but keep it evenly moist without becoming waterlogged. During the spring and summer, water the plant when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. In winter, reduce watering as the plant is less active. Over-watering can lead to root rot, so it's crucial to let the soil dry out slightly between waterings. Consider mulching around the base to retain soil moisture, especially during hot or windy conditions, but keep the mulch away from the stem to prevent decay."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pseudopanax lessonii thrives in a location with full sun to partial shade. It prefers at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight each day to ensure robust growth and vibrant foliage. In regions with particularly intense sun, some afternoon shade may be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. If grown in too much shade, the plant may become leggy and lose its vibrant coloration. Consider positioning it where it can receive morning sun and some afternoon shade, especially in hotter climates, to balance light exposure and keep the foliage healthy."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Pseudopanax lessonii is essential for maintaining its shape and encouraging healthy growth. The best time to prune is late winter to early spring, before new growth starts. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to improve airflow and light penetration within the plant. You can also trim back any excessively long shoots to maintain the desired shape. Use clean, sharp pruning tools to make precise cuts just above a leaf node or branch junction. Regular pruning will help keep the plant compact and bushy, supporting its overall health and appearance."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Houpara","description":"Pseudopanax lessonii, or houpara, is a New Zealand native tree belonging to the family Araliaceae. Houpara is a shrub or tree up to 6 m tall, with stout branches. The leaves are crowded towards the tips of branchlets, and are 3- to 5- foliolate. Juvenile plants have larger leaves than adults. The petioles are 5-15Â cm long.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["Houpara"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Pseudopanax lessonii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18865,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Neomarica northiana requires moderate watering, allowing the top inch of the soil to dry out between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure the pot has adequate drainage and avoid letting the plant sit in water. During the growing season in spring and summer, keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. In the fall and winter, reduce the frequency of watering as the plant enters a period of dormancy. Always adjust watering based on environmental conditions and the plant's specific needs."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Neomarica northiana thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. It can tolerate some direct sunlight, especially morning sun, but too much direct sun, particularly in the afternoon, can scorch the leaves. A location with filtered sunlight, such as near an east or north-facing window, is ideal. If growing outdoors, an area with partial shade is suitable. The plant can adapt to lower light conditions, but this may reduce flowering. Ensure that the plant receives around 4 to 6 hours of indirect sunlight daily for optimum growth and bloom production."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Neomarica northiana is minimal but involves removing dead or damaged leaves to promote healthy growth and prevent disease. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to cut leaves as close to the base as possible. This can be done at any time of the year, although it's often best to perform major pruning during the active growing season. Regularly check for dead flower stalks and remove them to encourage new growth. Avoid heavy pruning as this plant naturally has a graceful arching form that doesn't require significant shaping."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Walking iris","description":"Neomarica northiana, also known as North's false flag or walking iris, is a flowering plant, native to Brazil, with rhizomatous rootstock of the small genus of Neomarica, related to the large Iris family....","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Brazil"],"other_name":["Walking iris"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Scale insects","Aphids"],"propagation":["Division","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Neomarica northiana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19169,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Searsia laevigata is adapted to survive in drought-prone environments, so it prefers to be on the drier side. Water this plant sparingly, allowing the soil to dry out almost completely between waterings. During the active growing season in spring and summer, you may water more frequently, but be cautious of overwatering. Reduce watering significantly in fall and winter when the plant is dormant. Always check the top 2-3 inches of soil for moisture before watering to prevent root rot, which can occur if the roots are left sitting in water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Searsia laevigata thrives in full sun to partial shade settings. For optimal growth and a healthy appearance, provide it with at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. If planted in a region with intense afternoon sun, it may benefit from some partial shade during the hottest part of the day. When grown indoors, place it near a south or west-facing window to ensure it receives ample light. This plant can tolerate partial shade, but insufficient sunlight might lead to leggy growth or reduced vigor."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Searsia laevigata should be done primarily to maintain its shape and remove any dead or diseased branches. It is best to prune in late winter or early spring, just before the new growth begins. Use sharp, clean pruning shears to make crisp cuts, and trim back any crossing or rubbing branches to improve air circulation. If the plant is growing too vigorously, selective pruning can help control its size. Always aim to create an open canopy to allow sunlight to penetrate through the foliage, which promotes healthy growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Dune Currantrhus","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Dune Currantrhus"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Searsia laevigata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18466,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Claviceps purpurea, also known as ergot, is not a plant but a fungus, and it does not require regular watering like typical garden plants. It primarily infects rye and other cereals under wet, humid conditions. To control its spread, proper moisture management is essential in agricultural settings. Ergot grows when fields are damp, so effective drainage and avoiding excessive irrigation in susceptible crops can help reduce its incidence. Monitoring cereal crops for symptoms during rainy periods and ensuring good air circulation in fields can also prove beneficial."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Claviceps purpurea does not require sunlight as it is a fungus and relies on host plants for nutrients. It thrives in shaded and humid conditions typical of densely planted cereal crops. Controlling environmental conditions by ensuring cereals are not overly shaded and receive appropriate light exposure can help reduce ergot infections. Maintaining adequate sunlight levels helps decrease humidity, reducing favorable conditions for the fungus. Proper field management to allow sunlight penetration can be an indirect strategy to manage its spread in crop fields."},{"type":"pruning","description":"As Claviceps purpurea is a fungal organism and not a plant, pruning is not applicable for its management. Instead, focus should be on managing and reducing its spread in crops such as rye. Crop rotation and removal of infected plant debris can help minimize the presence of ergot sclerotia, which are the resting structures that overwinter in soil. Implementing harvesting techniques that reduce grain contamination, and cleaning equipment thoroughly to remove ergot bodies, can aid in controlling this fungus effectively across planting seasons."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Rye Ergot","description":"Claviceps purpurea is an ergot fungus that grows on the ears of rye and related cereal and forage plants. Consumption of grains or seeds contaminated with the survival structure of this fungus, the ergot sclerotium, can cause ergotism in humans and other mammals. C. purpurea most commonly affects outcrossing species such as rye (its most common host), as well as triticale, wheat and barley. It affects oats only rarely.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Purple\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"High","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Rye Ergot"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Claviceps purpurea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Afternoon"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19855,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Senegalia roemeriana, commonly known as Roemer's acacia, thrives in dry climates and is quite drought-tolerant. Water this plant sparingly, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings to prevent root rot. During the active growing season, water deeply but infrequently, roughly every 10-14 days, depending on climatic conditions. In winter, reduce the watering frequency even further as the plant enters a semi-dormant phase. Overwatering can be detrimental to its health, so ensure the soil has excellent drainage and always check the topsoil for dryness before watering again."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Senegalia roemeriana requires ample sunlight to thrive, best suited for locations with full sun exposure for at least 6 to 8 hours per day. This plant is well-adapted to the bright, intense light conditions found in its native arid habitats. When grown indoors, place it near a south-facing window where it can receive the maximum amount of light. If grown outdoors, select a spot that is not shaded by larger plants or structures. Insufficient sunlight can lead to leggy growth and reduced blooming, so ensure it receives adequate light for optimal health and vitality."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Roemer's acacia lightly to maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches. Cut back long stems to promote a more compact form, and thin out crowded branches to improve airflow within the canopy. Avoid excessive pruning as it can stress the plant; instead, aim to maintain its natural shape while controlling its size and removing any unwanted growth near the ground or trunk."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Roundflower Catclaw","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["Roundflower Catclaw"],"pest_susceptibility":["Leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Senegalia roemeriana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Mist the surroundings lightly if necessary to maintain humidity, especially in dry conditions, but ensure the substrate or soil is only slightly damp, not soggy."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Boletus separans, like most fungi, thrives in shaded environments. When cultivating or if found in the wild, it typically grows under the canopy of trees where it receives dappled sunlight at most. Direct sunlight is not required and can be detrimental if it dries out the damp conditions fungi prefer. Ensure that the growing area mimics a forest floor with ample indirect light and shade to maintain the right balance for healthy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Fungi do not require pruning like plants. For Boletus separans, consider 'pruning' as managing its environmental conditions to prevent the growth of competing fungi. If cultivating, ensure the substrate is free of weeds and other fungal spores that may compete. Ensuring ample sunlight not only supports flowering but also aids in the development of robust corms. If grown in containers, consider moving them to sunnier spots throughout the day to maximize light exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Gladiolus maculatus primarily involves removing spent flowers to encourage continued blooming and maintain the plant's appearance. Cut the flower spikes close to the ground once they've finished blooming. This practice not only promotes a tidy garden but also redirects the plant's energy toward developing healthier corms for the next growing season. Additionally, remove any brown or dead leaves regularly to prevent disease. Avoid excessive pruning, as the foliage is crucial for photosynthesis, which helps in storing energy within the corms."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Speckle-brown Afrikaner","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Speckle-brown Afrikaner"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Thrips"],"propagation":["Bulb division"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Gladiolus maculatus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19170,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Linum monogynum, commonly known as New Zealand Linen Flax, prefers well-draining soil and should be watered moderately. During the growing season, which is typically spring and summer, increase the frequency of watering to ensure the plant remains hydrated. In contrast, reduce watering in the fall and winter when the plant's growth slows down. Always consider environmental conditions, and adjust watering frequency accordingly to prevent waterlogging."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Linum monogynum thrives in full sun and requires a lot of direct sunlight to grow optimally. It is best placed in a location where it can receive at least 6 hours of sunlight per day. This plant can tolerate partial shade, but it may not flower as profusely as it would in full sun conditions. In regions with extremely hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from harsh sunlight and prevent scorching of the leaves. Proper light exposure is crucial for the vibrant blooms and overall health of the plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Linum monogynum should be done to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. Annual pruning is generally sufficient and should be carried out after the flowering season. Remove any dead or damaged stems and spent flowers to promote new growth. Cutting back the plant by about one-third can help to encourage bushier growth. Be sure to use clean, sharp pruning shears to avoid damaging the plant. Always take care not to remove too much foliage at once, as this can stress the plant. Regular deadheading can promote a prolonged flowering period."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"New Zealand linen flax","description":"Linum monogynum (common names rauhuia, native linen, New Zealand linen flax) is a short-lived perennial or woody subshrub endemic to North Island, South Island, Stewart Island, and the Chatham Islands of New Zealand. Ensure the plant is situated where it can receive ample light to maintain its health and ornamental appeal."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Austroderia richardii should be done annually in late winter or early spring before new growth appears. Maintaining consistent lighting conditions will promote healthy growth and help the plant retain its vibrant green color."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Pteris macilenta involves removing dead or damaged fronds to maintain the plant's health and aesthetic appeal. You should inspect the plant regularly and use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to cut off any brown, yellow, or wilted fronds at their base. This not only tidies up the plant but also encourages new growth. Avoid excessive pruning, as Pteris macilenta relies on its foliage for photosynthesis. Remove only what is necessary to improve air circulation and light penetration, which helps prevent fungal diseases. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19367,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Vernicia montana, commonly known as the Chinese wood oil tree, prefers consistent soil moisture. It should be watered regularly, especially during dry spells or when planted in containers, but it is crucial not to over-water as it can lead to root rot. Ensure the soil is well-draining and allow the top few inches to dry out between waterings. During the growing season, more frequent watering may be necessary, while in the dormant season, reduce the amount to avoid excess moisture. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and keep the roots cool."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Vernicia montana thrives in full sunlight to partial shade. It requires at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth and flowering. In regions with particularly intense sunlight, some afternoon shade may be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. If growing the plant indoors or in a greenhouse setting, ensure it is placed in a well-lit area, preferably near a south or west-facing window. Proper sunlight exposure is crucial for vigorous growth and abundant seed production, which is essential for its use in oil production."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Vernicia montana should ideally be done in late winter or early spring when the tree is still dormant. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches, and thin out crowded areas to increase air circulation within the canopy. This helps prevent disease and promotes healthy growth. Prune selectively to maintain the desired shape and size, as well as to encourage the tree's natural form. Regular pruning can also promote better light penetration, which supports flowering and seed production. Use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts and minimize stress to the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"mu oil tree","description":"Vernicia montana, the mu oil tree, or chine wood oil tree, is a species of Vernicia in the spurge family, native to Southeast Asia (including Myanmar, Thailand, Vietnam), southern China, and Taiwan. It is a medium-sized deciduous tree reaching a height 20 metres (66Â ft). The Latin specific epithet montana refers to mountains or coming from mountains. The leaves are large with three lobes. The monoecious white-petaled flowers emerged as inflorescences, containing both male and female flowers.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["China","Vietnam"],"other_name":["mu oil tree"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Vernicia montana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Ensure the plant is protected from strong, direct sunlight especially during peak hours."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Hymenophyllum dilatatum involves removing dead or damaged fronds to encourage new growth and maintain plant health. Inspect the plant regularly for any browning or deteriorating fronds and, using sterilized scissors, carefully trim these at the base. Avoid excessive pruning, as filmy ferns are delicate plants that do not respond well to heavy trimming. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19265,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Crassula rupestris, also known as the Baby's Necklace, is a succulent that requires careful watering to thrive. During the growing season, typically spring and summer, water the plant thoroughly when the soil is dry to touch, approximately once every 1-2 weeks depending on your local humidity and temperature conditions. Ensure the pot has good drainage to prevent water from sitting in the soil. In the fall and winter, reduce watering significantly, allowing the soil to dry out more completely between waterings, as overwatering during these dormant periods can lead to root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Crassula rupestris prefers bright, indirect sunlight for optimal growth. While it can tolerate some direct sunlight, especially in the early morning or late afternoon, too much intense direct light may cause leaf scorch or sunburn. Ideally, place the plant near a south or west-facing window where it can receive several hours of indirect light daily. If natural light is inadequate, especially during winter, consider supplementing with a grow light to ensure the plant receives enough energy to maintain its health and vibrant appearance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Crassula rupestris is generally minimal, as these plants maintain a neat form naturally. However, to encourage a bushier growth habit and remove any dead or excess leaves, you can trim the plant carefully. The best time for pruning is during its active growing season in spring or summer. Use sterilized scissors or shears to make clean cuts just above a leaf node or stem joint. Pruning off easily broken or damaged stems can also enhance the plant's appearance and health, while providing an opportunity to control and shape its growth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Kebab Bush","description":"Crassula rupestris, called buttons on a string, is a species of Crassula native to the Cape Provinces of South Africa. It has gained the Royal Horticultural Society's Award of Garden Merit. It is also called bead vine, necklace vine, and rosary vine.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Kebab Bush"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Crassula rupestris"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19857,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Panaeolus foenisecii, commonly known as the lawn mower's mushroom, does not require traditional watering care as it is a naturally occurring lawn mushroom. It typically appears on well-watered lawns, especially after rain. To thrive, ensure the grass or lawn is maintained with sufficient moisture, mimicking its natural late spring to autumn conditions. Avoid overwatering as it can lead to other fungi or pathogens that might harm the grass. Maintaining a healthy lawn ecosystem will naturally support this fungus if it is present."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Panaeolus foenisecii commonly grows in grassy areas exposed to sunlight but can tolerate partial shade. It thrives in a wide range of light conditions found in lawns. The presence of sunlight indirectly affects its growth by influencing the health and moisture level of the grass. Keeping your lawn healthy with adequate sunlight will naturally support the growth conditions it requires. However, excessive direct sunlight can dry out the lawn, so balance is key - maintain partial sunlight exposure for optimal fungus habitation."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Since Panaeolus foenisecii is a type of mushroom, it doesn't require pruning like a typical garden plant. However, if you wish to control its presence in your lawn or garden, you can manually remove the mushrooms by hand, especially before they release spores. Regularly mowing the lawn will also help manage their numbers. Ensure that you handle the mushrooms with care, as they are often mistaken for other potentially harmful species. Dispose of them safely to limit spore spread, if desired."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Mower's Mushroom","description":"Panaeolus foenisecii, commonly called the mower's mushroom, haymaker or brown hay mushroom, is a very common and widely distributed little brown mushroom often found on lawns. In 1963 Tyler and Smith found that this mushroom contains serotonin, 5-HTP and 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid. In many field guides it is erroneously listed as psychoactive, however the mushroom does not produce any hallucingenic effects.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":[],"other_name":["Mower's Mushroom"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["January"],"scientific_name":["Panaeolus foenisecii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18373,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Craterellus tubaeformis, commonly known as the Funnel Chanterelle, is a type of mushroom rather than a plant that requires specific conditions for optimal growth. As a fungi growing in moist forest environments, it does not need manual watering like plants but requires a habitat with high humidity. In cultivation, ensure the substrate is kept damp but not waterlogged, mimicking its natural forest floor environment. Over-saturation can lead to decay or mold, so good drainage is vital. Watering should mimic natural rainfall cycles, allowing the surface to dry slightly between waterings, which helps prevent fungal diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Craterellus tubaeformis thrives in shaded or partially shaded environments typical of forest floors. Direct sunlight can dry out the substrate, reducing humidity levels vital for its growth. When cultivating Funnel Chanterelles, replicate their natural habitat by providing plenty of indirect, dappled light, or a consistently shaded part of your garden. The environment should be cool and moist, as these mushrooms favor temperate climates with high humidity. Shield them from harsh sunlight and wind, which can desiccate the mushrooms and hinder their development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning isnât a traditional care practice for fungi like Craterellus tubaeformis, but it involves careful harvesting. These mushrooms should be gently twisted or cut at the stemâs base when collecting, ensuring not to damage the mycelium network below. This allows the fungi to continue growing and producing more fruiting bodies in the future. Removing debris and other competing vegetation around the mushrooms can promote healthy growth. This is less about pruning and more about maintaining optimal growth conditions, allowing the fungi to flourish without hindrance from competitors."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Yellowfoot","description":"Craterellus tubaeformis (formerly Cantharellus tubaeformis) is an edible fungus, also known as Yellowfoot, winter mushroom, or Funnel Chanterelle. It is mycorrhizal, forming symbiotic associations with plants, making it very challenging to cultivate. It is smaller than the golden chanterelle (Cantharellus cibarius) and has a dark brown cap with paler gills and a hollow yellow stem. C. tubaeformis tastes stronger but less fruity than the golden chanterelle. It has a very distinctive smokey, peppery taste when raw....","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America","Europe"],"other_name":["Yellowfoot"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Craterellus tubaeformis"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It's important to use well-draining soil to prevent water from accumulating and to avoid root rot, making sure that excess water drains out of the pot or garden bed effectively."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lysimachia monelli thrives in full sun to partial shade. In periods of heat or drought, increase watering to prevent the soil from completely drying out; a thick layer of mulch can help retain moisture around the roots. Ensure your plant site allows for good air circulation to prevent moisture-related diseases."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ranunculus polyanthemos is primarily focused on removing spent blooms and maintaining a tidy appearance. Deadhead faded flowers regularly during the growing season by cutting them back to a healthy pair of leaves; this encourages further blooming and prevents the plant from expending energy on seed production. At the end of the flowering season, you can cut back the foliage to tidy up the plant, but ensure some leaves remain to feed the bulb. In early spring, remove any dead or damaged growth to promote healthy new shoots."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Multi-flowered Buttercup","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Multi-flowered Buttercup"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Ranunculus polyanthemos"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

If you notice the host plant wilting or showing signs of dehydration, it may be necessary to increase the watering frequency for your host plant. Pay attention to the specific requirements of the host species to ensure both plants are receiving appropriate light levels for optimal health and growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Aphyllon californicum is generally not required, as this parasitic plant has a unique lifestyle dependent on its host. However, managing the host plant can indirectly affect the health of the Broomrape. Regularly inspect both the host and the Aphyllon for signs of stress or infestation, and remove any affected parts to prevent the spread of disease. Overwatering can cause root rot, so it's crucial to ensure proper drainage. Pruning not only helps in maintaining the plant's health but also enhances air circulation, reducing the risk of disease. Avoid cutting into the old wood as it may not regrow well. Light pruning can also be done throughout the growing season to harvest leaves or flowers."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Spanish Oregano","description":"Thymus capitatus is a compact, woody perennial native to Mediterranean Europe and Turkey, more commonly known as conehead thyme, Persian-hyssop and Spanish oregano. It is important to ensure that the soil does not dry out completely between waterings. During its active growth period in spring and early summer, increase watering frequency, keeping the soil evenly moist but not waterlogged to avoid root rot. In the dormant period, usually in late summer or fall, reduce watering slightly but still maintain moisture. To determine when it's time to water, check the top inch of soil; if it feels dry to the touch, it's time to water. Avoid overhead watering to prevent fungal diseases on the leaves."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Viola uniflora enjoys partial shade to full sun conditions, but it typically thrives best in locations where it receives morning sun and afternoon shade, mimicking its natural woodland habitat. Too much direct, harsh midday sunlight can scorch the leaves, so if it's planted in a full sun location, ensure that it is protected during the peak sun hours. In particularly hot climates, additional shade is beneficial. Ensure that the location also has good air circulation to prevent mildew if planted in shadier settings. Observing the plant's growth will help you determine if it needs more or less light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Viola uniflora is minimal and primarily involves removing dead or damaged leaves to maintain plant health and improve air circulation. After the flowering period, spent blooms should be removed to encourage further blooming and prevent seed formation, which can sap energy from the plant. Annual maintenance pruning is usually carried out in early spring to tidy up the plant before its growth spurt. Trim any foliage that appears ragged or discolored. Be sure to use clean, sharp tools to prevent diseases and provide neat cuts close to the base without damaging the base or surrounding healthy leaves."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Siberian Violet","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Asia","North America"],"other_name":["Siberian Violet"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Viola uniflora"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19369,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Mycena lazulina is a species of mushroom typically found in forested areas with high humidity. Generally, mushrooms like Mycena lazulina require minimal direct watering in a natural setting. However, if cultivating them or ensuring their continued growth in a garden setting, maintain a moist environment by spraying water to mimic a damp forest floor, being cautious to avoid overly soggy conditions that could harm the fungi. Ensure good drainage in the substrate to prevent waterlogging, which can be detrimental to their growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Mycena lazulina mushrooms thrive in low-light conditions typical of their natural habitat on the forest floor. They prefer indirect light filtered by trees, perhaps receiving dappled sunlight in a natural woodland setting. If cultivating, simulate these conditions by providing shade or maintaining them indoors under soft, diffuse light. Avoid direct sunlight as it can dry out the substrate and create inhospitable conditions for growth, maintaining humidity while preventing direct exposure ensures optimal mushroom health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable to Mycena lazulina in the traditional sense used for garden plants. Instead, ensure proper conditions to minimize competition and remove any dead or decayed fruiting bodies promptly to prevent disease spread. Cleaning up debris and maintaining healthy organic matter can support their growth environment. Observing changes and regulating conditions like moisture and ventilation helps manage wild or cultivated patches and encourages flourishing populations."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"tiny blue lights","description":"Mycena lazulina is a bioluminescent species of mushroom in the family Mycenaceae. It was first described in 2016.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Australia"],"other_name":["tiny blue lights"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Mycena lazulina"],"soil":["Well-drained","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18571,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Enchylaena tomentosa, commonly known as Ruby Saltbush, is a drought-tolerant plant that requires minimal watering once established. During the initial planting phase, water regularly to promote root development. After establishment, it thrives with only occasional watering. Typically, watering once every two weeks is sufficient in the growing season, especially in hot, dry climates. Allow the soil to dry out between waterings to avoid overwatering, which can lead to root rot. In cooler months, water sparingly as the plant enters dormancy and requires less moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Enchylaena tomentosa thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, the plant should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day to ensure vigorous growth and the best fruit production. In regions with extremely hot climates, some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from the harshest sun. However, too much shade can cause the plant to become leggy and reduce its flourishing capacity. Ensure the planting site has good air circulation and is not in deep shade to maintain healthy foliage and overall plant vigor."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Enchylaena tomentosa should be done to maintain shape and encourage bushy growth. This can be performed once a year, ideally in early spring. Use sharp, clean pruning shears to remove any dead or diseased branches. Lightly trimming the tips will promote denser foliage. Avoid heavy pruning, as this could stress the plant. Regularly remove suckers and any leggy growth to maintain a compact appearance. Additionally, trim down any stems that detract energy from the main branches to enhance flowering and overall appearance."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Barrier Saltbush","description":"Enchylaena tomentosa, commonly known as barrier saltbush or ruby saltbush, is a small native shrub of Australia.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Australia"],"other_name":["Barrier Saltbush"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Enchylaena tomentosa"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18973,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Plectranthus barbatus, commonly known as Indian Coleus, prefers well-draining soil and should be watered moderately. Allow the top 1-2 inches of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot, as this plant does not like to sit in soggy soil. Water more frequently during the growing season (spring and summer) and reduce during the dormant period (fall and winter). Overwatering is a common issue, so ensure good drainage and avoid leaving the plant in standing water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Plectranthus barbatus thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. It can tolerate some direct sun, especially morning sun, but prolonged exposure to harsh midday or afternoon sun can scorch the leaves. If grown indoors, placing the plant near a window with filtered light is ideal. In outdoor settings, a spot that receives partial shade or dappled sunlight works well. Too little light can cause the plant to become leggy, so balance is key to maintaining its vibrant appearance and health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Plectranthus barbatus is essential to maintain its shape and promote bushier growth. It is best done in early spring before new growth begins. Use clean, sharp shears to trim back any leggy or overgrown stems, focusing on stems that are crossing or growing inwards. Remove dead or yellowing leaves regularly to keep the plant healthy. Regular pinching of the growing tips can encourage a fuller appearance and more lateral growth, helping the plant remain vigorous and attractive."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Woolly Plectranthus","description":"Plectranthus barbatus, also known by the synonym Coleus forskohlii and vernacular names forskohlii and Indian coleus, is a tropical perennial plant related to the typical coleus species. It produces forskolin, an extract useful for pharmaceutical preparations and research in cell biology.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Africa"],"other_name":["Woolly Plectranthus"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["November"],"scientific_name":["Plectranthus barbatus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18773,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pterostylis montana, commonly known as the Mountain Greenhood, requires consistent watering during its active growing season, which typically occurs in winter to spring. The soil should be kept moist but not waterlogged, ensuring adequate drainage to prevent root rot. Reduce watering as the plant enters dormancy, usually in the warmer months. Misting can help maintain humidity around the plant. Be cautious not to let the potting mix dry out completely, as this can hinder the flower's development and the plant's growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pterostylis montana prefers bright, indirect sunlight. Direct sun exposure, especially during the hotter parts of the day, can scorch its delicate leaves. Ideally, it should be placed in a location with filtered or dappled light, such as near a north-facing window in the Southern Hemisphere or a south-facing window in the Northern Hemisphere. If growing outdoors, find a spot with partial shade or under the canopy of taller plants. Proper lighting conditions are crucial for optimal growth and flowering of the Mountain Greenhood."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Pterostylis montana involves removing any dead or damaged leaves and old flower spikes after the flowering season. This helps to keep the plant healthy and encourages new growth in the next season. It's important to use clean, sharp scissors or pruning tools to avoid spreading disease. Carefully trim the leaves and flower stems at their base without harming the surrounding healthy foliage or the bulb from which they arise. Regular maintenance will promote a more robust plant and more prolific blooming in subsequent seasons."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"New Zealand mountain greenhood","description":"Pterostylis montana is a species of greenhood orchid endemic to New Zealand. Flowering plants have erect, linear leaves on the flowering stem with a single green flower with translucent white stripes and an unusual twisted labellum.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Australia"],"other_name":["New Zealand mountain greenhood"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Pterostylis montana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19267,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Crassula expansa, like most succulents, requires careful watering to prevent root rot. Water the plant deeply, but only when the soil is completely dry. This typically means watering every 1-2 weeks during the growing season (spring and summer) and reducing the frequency in the fall and winter when the plant is dormant. It's important to check that excess water can drain out from the bottom of the pot to prevent waterlogging, and an ideal soil mix would be well-draining, such as a cactus or succulent potting mix."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Crassula expansa thrives in bright, indirect sunlight, making it ideal for a sunny windowsill or a well-lit room. It can tolerate some direct sunlight, especially early morning or late afternoon sun, but too much intense, direct exposure can lead to leaf scorch. If grown outdoors, a spot with dappled sunlight or light shade is preferable. In lower light conditions, the plant may grow leggy and require more support. Regularly rotating the plant can help it grow evenly by ensuring all sides receive equal sunlight exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Crassula expansa is generally minimal, often only necessary to control its shape or size, or to remove dead or damaged foliage. It's best to prune the plant during its active growing period in spring and summer. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to make cuts just above a leaf node to encourage branching and fuller growth. Always ensure the tools are sterilized before use to prevent introducing disease to the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Fine Stonecrop","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Fine Stonecrop"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Crassula expansa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

This can be achieved by misting the environment or substrate with water regularly, ensuring that the habitat mimics its natural moist woodland conditions. It's crucial not to over-saturate the environment, as excessive water can lead to mold growth and deterioration of the mushroom."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Xanthoconium affine, as a wild mushroom, thrives in shaded and forested environments typical of its natural habitat. Direct sunlight can be detrimental, potentially drying out the fruiting bodies and inhibiting growth. Instead, aim for dappled or ambient light conditions that resemble the filtered sunlight that penetrates through the forest canopy, thus maintaining the humidity and cool conditions necessary for optimal growth of this mushroom."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable to Xanthoconium affine in the traditional sense as it is a species of mushroom rather than a plant. Gently removing spent or dead mushrooms as they appear will keep the growing area tidy and might promote the growth of new fruiting bodies."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"spotted bolete","description":"Xanthoconium affine is a species of bolete fungus of the genus Xanthoconium. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18273,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Calicotome villosa is a drought-tolerant plant, accustomed to the Mediterranean climate. It requires little water once established and does not need to be watered regularly. During the hotter months, occasional deep watering every two to three weeks will suffice, ensuring the soil is dry before watering again. In wetter months, natural rainfall is usually enough. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's important to ensure the soil has excellent drainage and avoid letting the plant sit in waterlogged conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Calicotome villosa thrives in full sun and needs at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily to produce abundant blooms. It can tolerate partial shade but flowers less prolifically under such conditions. For optimal growth and flowering, plant it in a location with maximum sun exposure. This plant is well adapted to sunny, dry environments typical of the Mediterranean habitat. Adequate sunlight also helps the plant remain dense and compact, preventing it from becoming leggy and sparse over time."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Calicotome villosa should be done in early spring before new growth begins. This helps maintain its shape and encourages bushier growth. It is important to remove any dead or damaged wood, and thin out older branches to allow air and light to penetrate the inner parts of the shrub. Avoid heavy pruning as it can harm the plant, and don't prune during flowering to allow the plant to develop seeds and pods naturally. Light trimming after flowering can help tidy up the plant without inhibiting its growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Spiny Broom","description":"Calicotome villosa, also known as hairy thorny broom and spiny broom, is a small shrubby tree native to the eastern Mediterranean region.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mediterranean regions"],"other_name":["Spiny Broom"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Calicotome villosa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

However, during its initial growth period, it's important to keep the soil slightly moist to encourage root development. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure the soil dries out between waterings. In hotter, drier climates, a deep watering every two weeks should suffice, while in cooler, wetter environments, less frequent watering is required."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Dorycnium hirsutum thrives in full sun, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth and flowering. Too little sunlight can result in leggy growth and poor flowering. If you're growing this plant in a region with very hot summers, providing some afternoon shade can protect it from scorching. It is adaptable to partial shade, but this might lead to reduced flowering and a less compact shape. Ensure it is placed in a spot where it can receive plenty of sunlight to maintain its dense and lush appearance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Dorycnium hirsutum is vital for maintaining its compact shape and promoting healthy growth. It's best to prune in early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead or damaged stems to prevent disease, and trim back old, woody growth to encourage new shoots. After the flowering period, light pruning can help maintain its shape and size. Regular deadheading of spent flowers will prolong the blooming season and encourage further blooming. Be cautious not to prune too harshly, as this can stress the plant and reduce its vitality."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Hairy Canary-clover","description":"Dorycnium hirsutum, common name: canary clover or hairy canary-clover, is a perennial plant belonging to the genus Dorycnium of the Fabaceae family.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Gray-green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mediterranean","Southern Europe"],"other_name":["Hairy Canary-clover"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Dorycnium hirsutum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In the dormant season, reduce watering slightly, allowing the soil to dry out a bit more between waterings. Always use water at room temperature, as cold water can shock the plant, and ensure proper drainage to prevent waterlogging and root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sticherus flabellatus thrives in bright, indirect light, simulating its natural understory environment in rainforests. Direct sunlight can scorch its fronds, so it's important to shield it from harsh rays by placing it near an east or north-facing window or providing filtered light through a sheer curtain. If growing outdoors, a location with dappled sunlight under taller plants or trees is ideal. In insufficient light, the plant may grow leggy, whereas too much direct sunlight can cause browning at the frond edges. Adjust positions as needed to optimize health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Sticherus flabellatus helps maintain its graceful appearance and promote healthy growth. Remove any old, yellowing, or damaged fronds at their base with clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears. Regularly thinning out older fronds encourages air circulation and light penetration to the inner areas of the plant, which is beneficial for new frond development. Prune during the growing season, typically in spring or early summer. Avoid cutting off new growth tips, as this can inhibit the plant's ability to develop new fronds."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Shiny fan fern","description":"Sticherus flabellatus is a small fern found in eastern Australia and in New Zealand northwards from the north-west of the South Island. A common and attractive plant with shiny dark foliage and with slightly toothed edges on the smallest parts of the fronds. Often seen in large numbers in suitably moist gullies, creeks or near waterfalls.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Australia","New Zealand"],"other_name":["Shiny fan fern"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Sticherus flabellatus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Avoid direct sunlight, especially strong midday rays, as this can dry out the substrate and damage the mycelium. An environment that can maintain cool and humid conditions while providing limited, filtered sunlight exposure will allow this fungus to thrive similar to its natural ecosystem."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not typically associated with fungi like Collybia eucalyptorum, as they do not have parts that benefit from traditional pruning methods used on plants. Instead, focus on harvesting. When foraging or cultivating, remove mature mushrooms gently by cutting or twisting them at the base when they are fully developed. Dispose of any decaying or unhealthy mushrooms to prevent disease spread or pest attraction. It is crucial to maintain a humid environment, as these mushrooms are accustomed to the damp, shaded areas of their natural habitat. Watering should be done in moderation; the substrate or growing medium should be kept moist but not overly saturated. Misting the environment or using a humidity tent can help maintain the moisture levels necessary for growth. Ensure that there is good air circulation to prevent excessive humidity which can lead to mold or other fungal infections."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lentinus sajor-caju mushrooms thrive in low-light conditions, akin to their natural habitats in shaded, forested areas. They require diffused or indirect lighting rather than direct sunlight, which can dry out the growing medium and harm the delicate mushrooms. A location with filtered light or a controlled environment with grow lights simulating the forest understory conditions is ideal. If grown indoors, placing them in a well-ventilated room with ambient light or under fluorescent grow lights will support their photosensitive nature and enhance their growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Unlike traditional plants, Lentinus sajor-caju does not require pruning in the conventional sense. However, it is important to regularly harvest the mature mushrooms to encourage continuous growth. Harvesting is done when the mushrooms have reached their desired size and before the caps open too wide. This is typically when the edges of the caps curve slightly inward, and the gills are still pale. Removing mature mushrooms also helps prevent them from rotting on the substrate, which can affect the growth environment and potentially inhibit further development."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Funnel Woodcap","description":"Lentinus sajor-caju (formerly known as Pleurotus sajor-caju) is a species of saprophytic mushroom.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Asia"],"other_name":["Funnel Woodcap"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Lentinus sajor-caju"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

If growing indoors or in a controlled environment, ensure that it receives enough light but is protected from direct sun rays which could lead to desiccation or burning."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Aphyllon corymbosum is generally not necessary, given its parasitic nature. However, if it spreads excessively or becomes unsightly, you can prune it back to control its size or to improve the aesthetics of the area. Trim the stems back cleanly with sterile scissors or pruners to avoid introducing disease. It's crucial to minimize damage to the host plant during pruning and ensure that any cuts are made above the point of attachment to the host. Regular inspection can prevent unwanted spreading."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Flat-top Broomrape","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Flat-top Broomrape"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Aphyllon corymbosum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19670,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Epithelantha greggii, commonly known as Button Cactus, requires careful watering to prevent root rot. It is a drought-tolerant plant that prefers to dry out completely between waterings. During the growing season, typically spring and summer, water thoroughly but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings. In contrast, during the winter dormant period, reduce watering significantly, providing just enough moisture to prevent the plant from shriveling. Avoid letting water sit on the surface of the cactus, as this can cause rot. Overwatering is the most common issue, so it's better to underwater than overwater this cactus."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Epithelantha greggii thrives in bright light conditions and requires full sunlight to maintain its compact, healthy growth. Ideally, place it in a location where it can receive at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight each day. If you are growing it indoors, a south or west-facing window is ideal. In hotter climates, it may benefit from some afternoon shade to prevent scorching. Monitor the plant for signs of too much or too little light, adjusting its position as necessary. Adequate sunlight exposure ensures the cactus remains vibrant and supports its flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Epithelantha greggii requires minimal pruning, as it naturally maintains a compact and spherical shape. Pruning is generally unnecessary, but you can remove any dead or damaged sections to promote a healthier appearance. If the cactus produces pups or offsets, you may wish to separate them to encourage growth or propagation. Use sterilized tools to prevent infection. After pruning or removing offsets, allow the wounded areas to callous over before returning the plant to its original watering schedule. It is important to avoid both overwatering, which can lead to root rot, and letting the soil dry out completely, as this can harm the plant. Reducing watering frequency during dormancy in summer can mimic its natural environment, preserving the plant's health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Corybas macranthus thrives in low to moderate light conditions, mimicking its natural understory habitat in forests where it receives dappled light. A north-facing window or a spot away from the window is ideal. Providing the right amount of light will help maintain healthy foliage and encourage the production of flowers during the blooming season."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Corybas macranthus generally involves only the removal of spent flowers or damaged leaves, as orchids do not require significant pruning compared to other plants. Dead leaves can also be pruned to improve airflow and reduce the risk of disease. Since these orchids are sensitive, care should be taken to use sterilized scissors or shears to prevent disease transmission."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Silver-back Spider-Orchid","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["Australia","New Zealand"],"other_name":["Silver-back Spider-Orchid"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spots"],"propagation":["Division","Tissue Culture"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Corybas macranthus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18775,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ranunculus reflexus prefers consistently moist but well-drained soil. Water the plant thoroughly when the top inch of the soil starts to dry out, making sure excess water drains away to prevent root rot. During the growing season, maintain even moisture by watering regularly, but reduce watering in the colder months when the plant's growth slows down. It's crucial not to let the soil dry out completely but also avoid letting it stay soggy for extended periods. If grown outdoors, rainfall may suffice, but additional watering may be needed during dry spells."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This species thrives in full sun to part shade, making it adaptable to various light conditions. Ideally, provide Ranunculus reflexus with at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight each day to ensure optimal growth and abundant flowering. If growing the plant indoors, place it near a south- or west-facing window where it can receive ample natural light. In hotter climates, it may benefit from some afternoon shade to protect it from intense midday sun, which can cause leaf scorch. Adjust the light accordingly to keep the plant healthy and vibrant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ranunculus reflexus involves removing spent flowers and any yellowing or dead leaves to encourage more blooms and maintain plant health. Deadheading, which is the removal of faded flowers, helps prevent the plant from setting seed and redirects energy back into flower production. Remove any dead or damaged leaves during the growing season to prevent disease. In the fall, it's beneficial to cut the plant back to the ground as it goes dormant, which will help rejuvenate the plant for the next season. It is essential to keep the soil medium slightly moist during the growing season from autumn to late spring. Water the plant once a week or when the top inch of the soil feels dry. Ensure proper drainage as waterlogged conditions can lead to root rot. During its dormant summer phase, reduce watering significantly, allowing the plant to dry out more between waterings. Outdoors, position the plant in partial shade to mimic its natural habitat. During the hottest part of the day, ensure it is protected from the sharp midday sun to prevent leaf burns and stress on the plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Serapias cordigera is generally minimal but necessary to maintain plant health. Remove spent flowers after they have wilted to encourage further blooming and prevent the plant from wasting energy on seed production. After the growing season ends and the leaves naturally begin to wither, trim back the dried foliage to facilitate new growth in the following season. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18872,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Aechmea fasciata, also known as the Urn Plant, thrives with moderate watering. It is essential to keep the central cup, or rosette, partially filled with water at all times, as this is its primary hydration method in the wild. Use rainwater or distilled water to avoid mineral build-up. Allow the soil to dry slightly between waterings, usually watering every 1-2 weeks, depending on the environment's humidity and temperature. Avoid overwatering, which can lead to root rot. Mist the leaves occasionally to maintain humidity, especially in dry indoor conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Aechmea fasciata prefers bright, indirect sunlight. Direct sunlight should be avoided as it can scorch the leaves. Place the plant near a window with filtered light or in a location where it receives dappled sunlight for optimal growth. In limited light conditions, such as north-facing rooms, the plant may not flower as profusely but will still grow. During the darker winter months, additional fluorescent grow lights can supplement natural light. Ideal temperatures range from 60Â°F to 80Â°F (15Â°C to 27Â°C), as the plant is not frost-tolerant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Aechmea fasciata involves removing dead or damaged leaves to maintain the plant's appearance and health. Carefully trim away any brown or wilting leaves at the base using a clean pair of scissors or pruning shears. This helps prevent disease and pest issues by improving air circulation. Once the plant finishes flowering, the old flower spike can be cut close to its base. Over time, the mother plant will produce offsets or pups, which can be separated for propagation once they reach a third of the parent plant's size. Minimal pruning is generally required beyond these steps."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Urn Plant","description":"Aechmea fasciata (silver vase, urn plant) is a species of flowering plant in the bromeliad family, native to Brazil. It has gained the Royal Horticultural Society's Award of Garden Merit.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Brazil"],"other_name":["Urn Plant"],"pest_susceptibility":["Mealybugs","Scale insects"],"propagation":["Offset Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Aechmea fasciata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Be mindful not to prune during its dormancy phases for ideal results."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Fan aloe","description":"Kumara plicatilis, formerly Aloe plicatilis, the fan-aloe, is a succulent plant endemic to a few mountains in the Fynbos ecoregion, of the Western Cape in South Africa. This plant is well-suited for the edges of ponds or water gardens where it can access a steady supply of water. Be cautious not to let the plant dry out, as it relies on abundant moisture to maintain health and vigor. If grown in pots, consider placing them in water-filled saucers or submerging them partway in a water feature."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Typha orientalis thrives in full sunlight conditions for optimal growth and flowering. It requires at least six hours of direct sunlight daily to maintain its vigorous growth and produce healthy foliage and robust flower spikes. While it can tolerate partial shade, the plant may not grow as vigorously or produce as many flowers. In areas that experience intense, scorching midday sun, providing some shade during the hottest part of the day can prevent leaf burn. Ensuring that Typha orientalis has access to ample sunlight will support its overall health and aesthetic appeal in a garden setting."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Typha orientalis involves removing old, brown, or damaged leaves to encourage new growth and improve the plant's appearance. Prune back the dead stems to just above the plant base in late winter or early spring before the new growth begins. This timing helps to prevent disease and provides a tidier look. Additionally, removing flower heads before they set seed can help control the spread, especially since Typha orientalis can be quite vigorous and form large colonies if left unchecked. Regular maintenance pruning will help manage plant size and prevent it from overtaking the surrounding area."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Oriental Cattail","description":"Typha orientalis, commonly known as bulrush, bullrush, cumbungi in Australia, or raupÅ in New Zealand, is a perennial herbaceous plant in the genus Typha. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18475,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Baeometra uniflora, also known as the soldier flower, requires moderate watering. During its growing season in the fall and winter, keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent rot. In the dormant summer months, reduce watering significantly, letting the soil dry out completely between watering sessions. Overwatering during dormancy should be avoided to maintain plant health. Using a well-draining soil will help prevent water retention that can lead to root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Baeometra uniflora thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. It prefers a well-lit position that receives at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial, especially during the peak of summer, to prevent the leaves from scorching. Insufficient sunlight can lead to sparse blooms and leggy growth. When planted in partial shade, ensure that it still receives a few hours of direct sunlight to maintain its vibrant appearance and encourage abundant flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Baeometra uniflora is generally minimal as the plant maintains a compact growth habit. Remove spent flowers to encourage prolonged blooming and prevent the plant from using its energy for seed production. Trim away any yellow or dead foliage at the base to keep the plant tidy and healthy. This can be done as needed throughout its growing season. Avoid aggressive pruning, as it is a bulbous plant that relies on its foliage for food storage after blooming has finished. Allow the foliage to naturally die back to nourish the bulb for the next season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Beetle Lily","description":"Baeometra is a genus in the family Colchicaceae containing a single species, Baeometra uniflora. It is native to South Africa, where it is commonly called beetle lily due to the dark markings on the tepals. The genus was erected when the British botanist Richard Salisbury described the species \"Baeometra columellaris\" in 1812, although the plant had already been discovered, described and painted in 1793 by the Austrian botanist Nikolaus Joseph von Jacquin under the name Melanthium...","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Beetle Lily"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Baeometra uniflora"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During dry spells, especially in the growing season, monitor the soil moisture and water if necessary to keep the plant healthy. Ensure it gets enough light, as insufficient sunlight can result in leggy growth and reduced blooming. If the water evaporates, particularly in hot weather, top up with fresh water to keep the plant healthy. While it can tolerate partial shade, insufficient light might lead to reduced flowering and less vigorous growth. Balancing direct sunlight and shade is crucial, especially in regions with intense summers."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ranunculus peltatus involves trimming away any dead or decaying foliage to maintain its health and appearance. Since it's an aquatic plant, check regularly for leaves that may be yellowing or decomposing due to prolonged submergence or lack of light. These should be carefully removed to prevent them from falling into the water and contributing to algae growth. It is best to water in the early morning or late afternoon to minimize evaporation and ensure the plant can absorb adequate moisture without the risk of fungal diseases that can occur with evening watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rosa glabrifolia thrives best in full sunlight, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal flowering and growth. Ensuring it gets an adequate amount of light is crucial for its health and to maximize its beautiful floral display throughout the growing season."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rosa glabrifolia is important for maintaining its shape and encouraging healthy growth. Prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove dead or damaged wood first, followed by any crossed branches to improve air circulation. Cut back stems and branches to outward-facing buds to shape the plant. Regularly deadhead spent flowers during the growing season to promote continual blooming. Hard pruning can be done every couple of years to rejuvenate the plant, ensuring it remains vigorous and maintains a healthy framework."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Russian rose","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Russian rose"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Black spot","Powdery mildew","Rust"],"propagation":["Cutting","Grafting Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Rosa glabrifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts and avoid causing undue stress to the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Cluster Fig","description":"Ficus racemosa (syn. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18678,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Crassula pellucida, like many succulents, prefers to dry out between waterings. It is important to wait until the soil is completely dry before watering again to prevent root rot. During the growing season, typically spring through early fall, it may require watering every 1-2 weeks. In winter, reduce watering frequency to once a month, as the plant's water needs decrease during dormancy. Always ensure that the pot has drainage holes to prevent water from sitting in the soil."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Crassula pellucida thrives best in bright, indirect sunlight, though it can tolerate some direct sun. A location that provides about 4-6 hours of morning sun or dappled shade throughout the day is ideal. Too much direct sunlight, especially during the hottest part of the day, can scorch the leaves, while too little light may cause the plant to become leggy. If growing indoors, a south or east-facing window can provide the necessary light, but be sure to adjust based on the plant's response."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Crassula pellucida helps maintain its shape and encourages bushier growth. Use sharp, clean scissors or pruning shears to trim back leggy or dead stems. Pruning is best done in the spring or early summer, which is the plant's active growing period. Remove any leaves with signs of disease to prevent the spread and improve air circulation around the plant. Avoid excessive pruning, and focus on removing about one-third of the plant at a time for healthier rejuvenation."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Crystal Stonecrop","description":"Crassula pellucida is a creeping, succulent ground-cover, or low-growing, spreading succulent shrub, indigenous to South Africa.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Crystal Stonecrop"],"pest_susceptibility":["Mealybugs","Aphids"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Crassula pellucida"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Avoid letting the soil dry out completely, as this can stress the plant and hinder its growth, but be careful not to overwater, as soggy soil can lead to root rot. It might require more frequent watering during dry spells, especially when it's actively growing. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and regulate temperature."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Primula meadia prefers partial to full shade environments, especially in regions with hot summers. It thrives under dappled sunlight, as it imitates its natural woodland habitat. In northern climates, it can tolerate more direct sunlight but should be shielded from harsh afternoon sun. Too much direct sunlight can scorch the leaves and negatively affect the plant's health. In shaded areas, the soil tends to retain moisture better, which complements its preference for moist conditions. Adjust placement as needed to protect it from extreme sunlight exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Primula meadia is generally minimal. After the blooming period, you can deadhead the spent flowers to prevent the plant from spreading seeds excessively, unless natural propagation is desired. Cut back the stems to the base once flowering has completed to maintain the plantâs appearance and direct energy back to the roots. Additionally, remove any dead or damaged leaves to improve air circulation and reduce the risk of fungal diseases. Clean pruning tools with alcohol to prevent disease spread. This generally occurs in late spring to early summer."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"eastern shooting star","description":"Dodecatheon meadia is a species of flowering plant in the family Primulaceae, native to North America.
