It grows in woods and prairies and tolerates partial shade.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["eastern shooting star"],"pest_susceptibility":["Slugs","Snails"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Primula meadia"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19577,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lanaria lanata requires moderate watering. It is essential to let the topsoil dry out slightly between waterings to avoid overwatering, which can harm the plant. During its active growing season, typically spring through summer, ensure the soil remains consistently moist but not soggy. During the dormant period in fall and winter, reduce watering frequency, allowing the plant to rest. It's crucial to use well-draining soil to prevent root rot caused by excessive moisture, and ensure any excess water is able to drain away promptly from the pot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lanaria lanata thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. It can tolerate filtered sunlight but should be protected from direct, harsh midday sun, which can scorch its leaves. Ideal locations include areas that receive morning sun or spots where the plant is exposed to diffused light through sheer curtains. If grown indoors, placing the plant near an east or west-facing window is preferable. However, ensure it does not sit too far from the light source to prevent leggy growth. Monitoring light exposure is key to maintaining the plant's health and vibrancy of blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lanaria lanata involves removing any dead or damaged foliage to promote healthy growth and improve the plant's appearance. This can be done as needed throughout the growing season. Additionally, after the flowering period, deadheading spent blooms can encourage further blooming and prevent the plant from expending energy on seed production. Use sterilized tools to make clean cuts, and avoid removing too much live tissue at once, which can stress the plant. Regular pruning also helps to prevent any pest or disease issues by allowing better air circulation around the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Lambstail","description":"Lanaria is a monotypic genus of flowering plants containing a single species, Lanaria lanata, endemic to the southern coast of South Africa where it is associated with the fynbos belt. Lanaria lanata is commonly known as Cape edelweiss or lambtails. The genus is placed in the monotypic family Lanariaceae, a family only recently recognized by taxonomists. The APG IV system of 2016 (unchanged from the 1998, the 2003 and 2009 versions) does recognize this family.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Lambstail"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Lanaria lanata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19865,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Reynoutria japonica, commonly known as Japanese knotweed, is a hardy plant that doesnât require frequent watering once established. It is highly adaptable, capable of withstanding drought conditions, but grows best with consistent moisture. When planting, ensure the soil remains moist but not waterlogged to promote healthy growth. As Japanese knotweed is invasive, keeping it well-contained is crucial, especially when providing water. Overwatering should be avoided to prevent making conditions ideal for its rampant spreading. During dry periods, check the soil to see if watering is necessary but typically, rainfall will suffice for established growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Japanese knotweed can tolerate a wide range of sunlight conditions but thrives best in full sun to partial shade. It is highly adaptable and can grow in shaded areas, which makes it quite invasive. For management and control, it's important to note that although it can survive in poor lighting, the growth will be less vigorous. When cultivating, placement in a location with a lot of direct sunlight will encourage rapid growth, but containment strategies should be in place. However, in sites where its growth needs to be controlled or limited, allowing more shade can potentially assist in managing its spread."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Japanese knotweed is crucial for its control and management, as it is an invasive species. Ideally, cutting back should occur regularly during the growing season to prevent it from spreading. Depriving it of sunlight via pruning can weaken the plant significantly over time by depleting its energy reserves. Ensure cuts are made close to the ground, and consider removing and disposing of the cut stems properly to prevent regrowth. Early summer, when itâs semi-grown, is a good time for a significant pruning session, followed by regular trims throughout summer and fall. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent the spread of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Japanese knotweed","description":"Reynoutria japonica, synonyms Fallopia japonica and Polygonum cuspidatum, is a large species of herbaceous perennial plant of the knotweed and buckwheat family Polygonaceae. It is commonly known as Asian knotweed or Japanese knotweed. It is native to East Asia in Japan, China and Korea. In North America and Europe, the species has successfully established itself in numerous habitats and is classified as an invasive species in several countries.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["Eastern Asia","Japan","China","Korea"],"other_name":["Japanese knotweed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Rhizome"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Reynoutria japonica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Clay","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19179,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Swietenia mahagoni, commonly known as the West Indian Mahogany, prefers consistent watering during its growing season but is quite drought-tolerant once established. In its initial growth phase, water deeply once or twice a week, allowing the soil to dry slightly between waterings to prevent root rot. Well-established trees can survive on rainfall but may require additional water in prolonged dry spells. Mulching around the base can help retain soil moisture, but avoid overwatering, especially in heavy clay soil, as this species does not appreciate sustained soggy conditions. Adjust watering based on local climate and rainfall."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Swietenia mahagoni thrives best in full sunlight, ideally needing at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily. While it can tolerate partial shade, optimal growth and wood quality occur when the tree is planted in a location that receives ample sunlight. Ensuring sufficient sunlight also helps in developing a strong, robust trunk and a healthy canopy. If grown in shaded conditions, the tree may become leggy and fail to develop its characteristic dense foliage. Therefore, when choosing a planting site, prioritize open areas free from competing shade of taller structures or trees."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Swietenia mahagoni generally involves maintaining its shape and encouraging strong structure. Prune during the dormant season, in late winter or early spring, before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to maintain tree health. Thinning out crowded areas can enhance air circulation within the canopy, reducing disease risk. Additionally, remove any suckers or water sprouts that may be detracting from the tree's desired form. Be cautious not to over-prune, as this can stress the tree, and always use clean, sharp tools to make smooth cuts."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"West Indian Mahogany","description":"Swietenia mahagoni, commonly known as the American Mahogany, Cuban Mahogany, Small-leaved Mahogany, and West Indian Mahogany, is a species of Swietenia native to southern Florida in the United States and islands in the Caribbean including the Bahamas, Cuba, Jamaica, Dominican Republic and Haiti . It is the species from which the original mahogany wood was produced.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Central America","Caribbean","South Florida"],"other_name":["West Indian Mahogany"],"pest_susceptibility":["Scale insects"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Swietenia mahagoni"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In contrast, during the cooler months, reduce watering as the plant's growth slows. Always check the top inch of soil before watering; if it's dry, it's time to water again. Using well-draining soil can help maintain appropriate moisture levels."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Osmitopsis asteriscoides thrives best under full sun. It requires abundant sunlight to grow and maintain its health, as plenty of light supports its flowering and overall vigor. Position the plant in a location where it can receive at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. If grown indoors, place it near a south-facing window that receives ample sunlight. In areas with very hot climates, provide some afternoon shade to prevent the foliage from scorching. Proper sunlight exposure will ensure robust growth and vibrant blooms throughout the growing season."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Osmitopsis asteriscoides can help promote a bushier growth and remove any dead or damaged stems or leaves. It is best to prune during the plantâs active growing season, typically in spring or early summer. Use sharp, clean pruning shears and make cuts just above a node to encourage new, healthy growth. Regularly remove any yellowing or dead foliage to maintain the plantâs appearance and health. Additionally, light pruning can stimulate more prolific flowering. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19674,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pilosella aurantiaca, commonly known as Orange Hawkweed, is a drought-tolerant plant that does not require frequent watering. It prefers dry to moderately moist soils. Water it only when the top few inches of soil are dry, typically about once a week during dry spells. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure the soil has excellent drainage. During the winter, reduce watering as the plant enters a dormant phase, and natural precipitation should suffice unless there are prolonged dry periods."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pilosella aurantiaca thrives in full sun environments, which means it needs at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. While it can tolerate partial shade, optimal growth and flowering are achieved when it receives full exposure to sunlight. In very hot climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to protect the plant from intense sun and heat. If grown indoors, place it in the sunniest spot available, such as a south-facing window. Consistent access to sunlight will ensure vibrant flower color and robust growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not particularly necessary for Pilosella aurantiaca, but occasional deadheading of spent flowers can encourage healthier growth and prevent unwanted seeding, as this plant can be invasive. If you wish to control its spread, cut back stems after flowering to prevent seed dispersal. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears, and make your cuts just above a healthy leaf bud or node. For general maintenance, remove any dead, damaged, or diseased foliage to help the plant stay healthy and tidy."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"orange hawkweed","description":"Pilosella aurantiaca (fox-and-cubs, orange hawk bit,:208 devil's paintbrush, grim-the-collier) is a perennial flowering plant in the daisy family Asteraceae native to alpine regions of central and southern Europe, where it is protected in several regions.","family":null,"flower_color":"Orange","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["orange hawkweed"],"pest_susceptibility":["Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Pilosella aurantiaca"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18679,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cyathophorum bulbosum, a species of moss, requires consistent moisture to thrive. The key to watering is to keep the substrate or soil consistently damp, but not waterlogged. Use room temperature, non-chlorinated water to avoid harming the moss. Since moss absorbs water through its entire surface, misting can be very effective. Itâs important to maintain humidity levels around 60-80% as well. Avoid letting the moss dry out completely as this can cause it to become dormant and lose its vibrant green color. During extremely dry periods, increase watering or mist more frequently."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cyathophorum bulbosum prefers indirect, filtered light and can thrive in shaded environments. Direct sunlight should be avoided as it can scorch the delicate moss tissue, leading to dehydration and browning. Ideally, it should be placed in a location where it can receive dappled sunlight or grow under the canopy of other plants that provide natural shading. If kept indoors, positioning the moss near a north-facing window or well-lit bathroom can be ideal, as these locations provide adequate light without risking direct exposure to strong rays. Maintaining stable lighting conditions helps keep the moss healthy and vibrant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cyathophorum bulbosum involves removing any dead or brown sections of the moss to encourage healthy growth and improve its appearance. This can be done gently with fingers or small, sharp scissors to avoid damaging the healthy parts. Regularly check for and gently trim away any overgrown or unsightly areas to maintain a tidy appearance. Pruning can also help prevent overcrowding and promote air circulation, which is beneficial for reducing the risk of mold or fungal issues. Always ensure that the tools used are clean to prevent infection or disease spread."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"quill moss","description":"Cyathophorum bulbosum, commonly known as quill moss or the false fern moss, is found in the eastern states of Australia (QLD, NSW, VIC, TAS and south-eastern SA) as well as Papua New Guinea, New Zealand, Auckland Islands, Chatham Island, Lord Howe Island and possibly Norfolk Island and New Ireland.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["New Zealand","Australia"],"other_name":["quill moss"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Division","Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Cyathophorum bulbosum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19578,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lessertia frutescens, commonly known as Sutherlandia or cancer bush, is a drought-resistant plant that requires minimal watering. It is best to allow the soil to dry out between waterings, particularly during cooler months. Water thoroughly when the top layer of soil feels dry, ensuring that the water drains well to prevent root rot. Over-watering should be avoided, as it can lead to fungal issues. In its natural habitat, which is arid, it adapts to infrequent rainfall, so it is crucial to mimic these conditions for a thriving plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lessertia frutescens flourishes in full sun positions but can tolerate partial shade. For optimal growth and blooming, plant it in an area where it receives at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight per day. Inadequate sunlight may lead to leggy growth and reduced flowering, so ensuring ample sunlight will help maintain its health and attractive appearance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lessertia frutescens is beneficial for encouraging bushier growth and maintaining a tidy shape. You can also trim back overgrown stems to maintain the desired shape and size, keeping in mind to not remove more than a third of the plant at once. Regular light pruning encourages more robust flowering and growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"cancer bush","description":"Sutherlandia frutescens (cancer bush, balloon pea, or sutherlandia; syn. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19472,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Berzelia intermedia prefers consistently moist soil, making it crucial to maintain a regular watering schedule. Ensure that the soil never dries out completely, but avoid waterlogging, which can harm the root system. During the growing season, particularly in the warmer months, increase watering frequency, but let the top inch of soil dry slightly between waterings to prevent soggy conditions. In winter, reduce the watering as the plant's growth slows down. It's advisable to use distilled or rainwater to reduce mineral build-up if your tap water is hard."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Berzelia intermedia thrives best in full sunlight to partial shade. It requires at least six hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth and flowering. If grown indoors, place the plant near a south or west-facing window where it receives ample light, but ensure the light is filtered to prevent leaf scorch. If exposed to intense afternoon sun, particularly in hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can protect the plant from too much heat stress. Monitoring the sunlight helps maintain a healthy, vibrant plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Berzelia intermedia involves removing dead or damaged stems and shaping the plant to promote a bushier growth. It's best done during the plant's dormant period or early spring before new growth begins. Use sharp, sterilized pruning shears to make clean cuts, and focus on cutting back up to one third of the older, woodier growth to encourage fresh growth. Deadheading spent flowers can also help redirect energy into new shoots. Be cautious not to over-prune, as this can stress the plant and reduce flowering."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Common Coppice Kolkol","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Common Coppice Kolkol"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Berzelia intermedia"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19767,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Phelipanche ramosa, commonly known as branched broomrape, is a parasitic plant that does not require conventional watering like other plants. Instead, it relies on a host plant to supply its water and nutrients. If you are managing an area infested with this plant and aim to control it, make sure to limit the water to the host plants to a minimum required for their survival, as over-irrigation could encourage the broomrape's growth. Regular monitoring of host plants for any signs of broomrape infestation can help manage its spread."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"As a root parasite, Phelipanche ramosa doesnât require direct sunlight since it doesnât photosynthesize in the traditional sense. Instead, its growth is dependent on the vigor and sunlight exposure of its host plants. If controlling this plant, consider minimizing ideal growing conditions for potential host plants, which include regular sunlight. Managing host plant density and canopy coverage can indirectly limit the broomrape's growth by reducing optimal growing conditions for its hosts."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Phelipanche ramosa generally does not require pruning since it is a parasitic plant and not grown intentionally. Pruning can be inappropriate unless trying to control its spread. In this context, removal of visible flowering stems before they set seed can help reduce its propagule pressure. It's crucial to carefully dispose of any parts removed to prevent seed dispersal. If infestations are severe in agricultural settings, integrated pest management strategies should be employed as pruning isn't typically effective against parasitic plants."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"hemp broomrape","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"High","origin":["Europe","Asia","Africa"],"other_name":["hemp broomrape"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Phelipanche ramosa"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18466,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Claviceps purpurea, also known as ergot, is not a plant but a fungus, and it does not require regular watering like typical garden plants. It primarily infects rye and other cereals under wet, humid conditions. To control its spread, proper moisture management is essential in agricultural settings. Ergot grows when fields are damp, so effective drainage and avoiding excessive irrigation in susceptible crops can help reduce its incidence. Monitoring cereal crops for symptoms during rainy periods and ensuring good air circulation in fields can also prove beneficial."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Claviceps purpurea does not require sunlight as it is a fungus and relies on host plants for nutrients. It thrives in shaded and humid conditions typical of densely planted cereal crops. Controlling environmental conditions by ensuring cereals are not overly shaded and receive appropriate light exposure can help reduce ergot infections. Maintaining adequate sunlight levels helps decrease humidity, reducing favorable conditions for the fungus. Proper field management to allow sunlight penetration can be an indirect strategy to manage its spread in crop fields."},{"type":"pruning","description":"As Claviceps purpurea is a fungal organism and not a plant, pruning is not applicable for its management. Instead, focus should be on managing and reducing its spread in crops such as rye. Crop rotation and removal of infected plant debris can help minimize the presence of ergot sclerotia, which are the resting structures that overwinter in soil. Implementing harvesting techniques that reduce grain contamination, and cleaning equipment thoroughly to remove ergot bodies, can aid in controlling this fungus effectively across planting seasons."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Rye Ergot","description":"Claviceps purpurea is an ergot fungus that grows on the ears of rye and related cereal and forage plants. Consumption of grains or seeds contaminated with the survival structure of this fungus, the ergot sclerotium, can cause ergotism in humans and other mammals. C. purpurea most commonly affects outcrossing species such as rye (its most common host), as well as triticale, wheat and barley. It affects oats only rarely.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Purple\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"High","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Rye Ergot"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Claviceps purpurea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Afternoon"}}

When grown indoors, place it near a south-facing window where it can receive the maximum amount of light. If grown outdoors, select a spot that is not shaded by larger plants or structures. Insufficient sunlight can lead to leggy growth and reduced blooming, so ensure it receives adequate light for optimal health and vitality."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Roemer's acacia lightly to maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches. Cut back long stems to promote a more compact form, and thin out crowded branches to improve airflow within the canopy. Avoid excessive pruning as it can stress the plant; instead, aim to maintain its natural shape while controlling its size and removing any unwanted growth near the ground or trunk."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Roundflower Catclaw","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["Roundflower Catclaw"],"pest_susceptibility":["Leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Senegalia roemeriana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is important to water them regularly during the growing season, typically spring and early summer, to keep the soil consistently moist but not soggy. Once its foliage dies back, which usually happens in late summer, you should reduce watering significantly as the plant enters a dormant period. During dormancy, ensure the soil doesnât completely dry out if dry conditions persist, especially in regions with little rainfall. Overwatering is the most common issue, so it's crucial to allow the soil to dry out slightly between waterings."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lycoris squamigera thrives best in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, these bulbs should be planted in a location where they can receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. Sunlight boosts the growth of their foliage and helps energy storage for flowering. However, in hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from intense heat. They are quite adaptable to different light conditions, but a lack of sufficient sunlight may lead to fewer blooms. Choose a spot with dappled or filtered light if planting in more shaded garden areas."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Lycoris squamigera involves removing dead foliage after it naturally dies back in the summer. When the leaves turn yellow and begin to wither, you can prune them off carefully to tidy the plant and prevent any potential disease issues. However, ensure that you do not cut the leaves while they are still green, as they need to photosynthesize and store energy for the following flowering season. No other major pruning is necessary for these low-maintenance bulbs, as they tend to thrive with minimal intervention once planted in a suitable environment."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Surprise Lily","description":"Lycoris squamigera (resurrection lily) is a plant in the amaryllis family, Amaryllidaceae, subfamily Amaryllidoideae. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19463,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Gladiolus maculatus requires moderate watering. During the growing season, usually from spring to early summer, keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Water the plant deeply once or twice a week, allowing the top layer of soil to dry out between waterings. It's essential to reduce watering as the plant approaches dormancy in late summer. During the dormant period, ensure the soil is dry to prevent the corms from rotting. Adjust your watering schedule based on rainfall and humidity, as these factors can influence the plant's moisture needs."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Gladiolus maculatus thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight each day to grow optimally. Ideal locations include spots that receive bright morning sunshine or afternoon sun. While they can endure partial shade, too little light may result in fewer blooms and leggier growth. Ensuring ample sunlight not only supports flowering but also aids in the development of robust corms. If grown in containers, consider moving them to sunnier spots throughout the day to maximize light exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Gladiolus maculatus primarily involves removing spent flowers to encourage continued blooming and maintain the plant's appearance. Cut the flower spikes close to the ground once they've finished blooming. This practice not only promotes a tidy garden but also redirects the plant's energy toward developing healthier corms for the next growing season. Additionally, remove any brown or dead leaves regularly to prevent disease. Avoid excessive pruning, as the foliage is crucial for photosynthesis, which helps in storing energy within the corms."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Speckle-brown Afrikaner","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Speckle-brown Afrikaner"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Thrips"],"propagation":["Bulb division"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Gladiolus maculatus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is important to consider the specific water needs of the host plant and adjust based on environmental conditions like temperature and humidity."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pear trees, which can host Gymnosporangium sabinae, typically require full sun to thrive. They should be planted in an area that receives at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight per day. Adequate sunlight helps in maintaining the health of the tree and can reduce the severity of rust infections by promoting strong, vigorous growth, which can be more resilient to pathogens. Proper spacing is also key to ensure good air circulation and light penetration to all parts of the tree."},{"type":"pruning","description":"For a plant affected by Gymnosporangium sabinae, primarily affecting pear trees or similar hosts, regular pruning is essential to remove any infected areas. Prune during the dormant season to prevent the spread of the rust. Make sure to remove and destroy any fallen leaves or branches that show signs of infection. This helps to minimize the places where spores can overwinter, thereby reducing the chance of re-infection in the spring."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Pear Rust","description":"Gymnosporangium sabinae (also Gymnosporangium fuscum and other names) (pear rust, European pear rust, or pear trellis rust) is a fungal heteroecious plant pathogen with Juniperus (juniper trees and shrubs) as the primary (telial) host and only Pyrus (pear trees) as secondary (aecial) hosts. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19665,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Anemone altaica, also known as the Siberian anemone, prefers consistently moist soil. It is important not to let the soil dry out completely, especially during the growing season in spring and early summer. Water the plant regularly, ensuring that the water permeates the soil deeply. Reduce watering in the dormant season during late summer and winter, but do not allow the soil to dry out entirely. Well-drained soil is essential to prevent waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. Mulching can help retain moisture in the soil."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Anemone altaica prefers partial to full shade, mimicking their natural woodland habitat. They thrive when exposed to dappled sunlight under tree canopies or situated in areas that receive morning sun and afternoon shade. While the plant can tolerate some direct sunlight, especially in cooler climates, too much intense sun, especially in the afternoon, can cause leaf scorch. Ensuring they are planted in a shaded environment will help maintain moist soil conditions and prevent the plant from drying out too quickly."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Anemone altaica is generally minimal. You should remove spent flowers and any withered or yellowing foliage to encourage a tidy appearance and prevent potential disease. In late autumn, after the plant has finished flowering, you can cut the plant back to ground level. This helps tidy up the garden space for winter and encourages healthy growth in the spring. Be cautious not to cut back too early while foliage is still green, as the plant uses it to store energy for the next growing season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Eastern Asia","Russia"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Anemone altaica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19464,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Crassula capensis, like most succulents, requires careful watering to prevent root rot. Water deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings. During the growing season, spring through fall, water the plant every one to two weeks, depending on your climate and the environment in which the plant is kept. In winter, reduce watering significantly; a monthly watering should suffice when the plant is mostly dormant. Always use well-draining soil to prevent excess moisture retention, and make sure the pot has drainage holes to allow any excess water to escape."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Crassula capensis thrives in bright, indirect sunlight but can also tolerate some direct sun. Ideally, provide them with around four to six hours of sunlight each day to mimic their natural habitat and encourage healthy growth. A south-facing window is a good location, but if the sun is too intense, consider moving them slightly away from the window or using a sheer curtain to diffuse the light. In lower light conditions, the plant may become leggy as it stretches towards the light, so adjusting its position periodically may be necessary to maintain compact growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Crassula capensis is not usually necessary but can help maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. Remove any dead or damaged leaves to promote air circulation around the plant. If the plant becomes leggy, you can trim back some of the longer stems to encourage branching. This should be done during the growing season, from spring through early summer. Ensure you use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to make clean cuts and prevent any potential disease. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19066,"attracts":["Bees","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"The Malus domestica, commonly known as the apple tree, requires consistent but moderate watering, especially during the growing season. Ensure the soil is well-drained to prevent waterlogging. Water deeply once a week in the absence of rain, increasing the frequency in sandy soils or during particularly hot and dry periods. Be careful not to overwater, as apple trees do not like soggy roots. Newly planted trees need more frequent watering until they are established. Applying mulch around the base can help retain moisture and reduce the need for frequent watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Apple trees, or Malus domestica, thrive in full sunlight, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sun each day for optimal growth and fruiting. Sunlight is crucial for flower and fruit development, and it also helps to prevent fungal diseases by keeping foliage dry. When planting an apple tree, choose a location that receives ample sunlight throughout the day and is free from shadows cast by taller trees or buildings. Proper sunlight exposure will ensure strong, healthy growth and maximize fruit yield and quality."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Malus domestica in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove dead, damaged, or diseased wood, and cut back any branches that cross or rub against each other. It's important to open up the center of the tree by removing crowding to facilitate air circulation and light penetration. This helps to prevent diseases and improve fruit quality. Aim to maintain a balanced shape and direct new growth to encourage an open and goblet-like form. Annual pruning also helps manage tree height and stimulates fruit production."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"apple","description":"An apple is an edible fruit produced by an apple tree (Malus domestica). Apple trees are cultivated worldwide and are the most widely grown species in the genus Malus. The tree originated in Central Asia, where its wild ancestor, Malus sieversii, is still found today. Apples have been grown for thousands of years in Asia and Europe and were brought to North America by European colonists. Apples have religious and mythological significance in many cultures, including...","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Central Asia"],"other_name":["apple"],"pest_susceptibility":["Apple scab","Codling moth","Fire blight"],"propagation":["Grafting Propagation","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Malus domestica"],"soil":["Loamy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is important not to overwater as it can lead to root rot. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. During the growing season, which is typically spring and summer, increase the frequency of watering to ensure the plant remains hydrated. In contrast, reduce watering in the fall and winter when the plant's growth slows down. Always consider environmental conditions, and adjust watering frequency accordingly to prevent waterlogging."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Linum monogynum thrives in full sun and requires a lot of direct sunlight to grow optimally. It is best placed in a location where it can receive at least 6 hours of sunlight per day. This plant can tolerate partial shade, but it may not flower as profusely as it would in full sun conditions. In regions with extremely hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from harsh sunlight and prevent scorching of the leaves. Proper light exposure is crucial for the vibrant blooms and overall health of the plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Linum monogynum should be done to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. Annual pruning is generally sufficient and should be carried out after the flowering season. Remove any dead or damaged stems and spent flowers to promote new growth. Cutting back the plant by about one-third can help to encourage bushier growth. Be sure to use clean, sharp pruning shears to avoid damaging the plant. Always take care not to remove too much foliage at once, as this can stress the plant. Regular deadheading can promote a prolonged flowering period."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"New Zealand linen flax","description":"Linum monogynum (common names rauhuia, native linen, New Zealand linen flax) is a short-lived perennial or woody subshrub endemic to North Island, South Island, Stewart Island, and the Chatham Islands of New Zealand. Maintaining consistent lighting conditions will promote healthy growth and help the plant retain its vibrant green color."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Pteris macilenta involves removing dead or damaged fronds to maintain the plant's health and aesthetic appeal. You should inspect the plant regularly and use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to cut off any brown, yellow, or wilted fronds at their base. This not only tidies up the plant but also encourages new growth. Avoid excessive pruning, as Pteris macilenta relies on its foliage for photosynthesis. Remove only what is necessary to improve air circulation and light penetration, which helps prevent fungal diseases. It should be watered regularly, especially during dry spells or when planted in containers, but it is crucial not to over-water as it can lead to root rot. Ensure the soil is well-draining and allow the top few inches to dry out between waterings. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and keep the roots cool."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Vernicia montana thrives in full sunlight to partial shade. It requires at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth and flowering. In regions with particularly intense sunlight, some afternoon shade may be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. Prune selectively to maintain the desired shape and size, as well as to encourage the tree's natural form. Regular pruning can also promote better light penetration, which supports flowering and seed production. Use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts and minimize stress to the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"mu oil tree","description":"Vernicia montana, the mu oil tree, or chine wood oil tree, is a species of Vernicia in the spurge family, native to Southeast Asia (including Myanmar, Thailand, Vietnam), southern China, and Taiwan. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19265,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Crassula rupestris, also known as the Baby's Necklace, is a succulent that requires careful watering to thrive. During the growing season, typically spring and summer, water the plant thoroughly when the soil is dry to touch, approximately once every 1-2 weeks depending on your local humidity and temperature conditions. Ensure the pot has good drainage to prevent water from sitting in the soil. In the fall and winter, reduce watering significantly, allowing the soil to dry out more completely between waterings, as overwatering during these dormant periods can lead to root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Crassula rupestris prefers bright, indirect sunlight for optimal growth. While it can tolerate some direct sunlight, especially in the early morning or late afternoon, too much intense direct light may cause leaf scorch or sunburn. Ideally, place the plant near a south or west-facing window where it can receive several hours of indirect light daily. If natural light is inadequate, especially during winter, consider supplementing with a grow light to ensure the plant receives enough energy to maintain its health and vibrant appearance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Crassula rupestris is generally minimal, as these plants maintain a neat form naturally. However, to encourage a bushier growth habit and remove any dead or excess leaves, you can trim the plant carefully. The best time for pruning is during its active growing season in spring or summer. Use sterilized scissors or shears to make clean cuts just above a leaf node or stem joint. Pruning off easily broken or damaged stems can also enhance the plant's appearance and health, while providing an opportunity to control and shape its growth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Kebab Bush","description":"Crassula rupestris, called buttons on a string, is a species of Crassula native to the Cape Provinces of South Africa. Avoid overwatering as it can lead to other fungi or pathogens that might harm the grass. Maintaining a healthy lawn ecosystem will naturally support this fungus if it is present."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Panaeolus foenisecii commonly grows in grassy areas exposed to sunlight but can tolerate partial shade. It thrives in a wide range of light conditions found in lawns. The presence of sunlight indirectly affects its growth by influencing the health and moisture level of the grass. Keeping your lawn healthy with adequate sunlight will naturally support the growth conditions it requires. However, excessive direct sunlight can dry out the lawn, so balance is key - maintain partial sunlight exposure for optimal fungus habitation."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Since Panaeolus foenisecii is a type of mushroom, it doesn't require pruning like a typical garden plant. However, if you wish to control its presence in your lawn or garden, you can manually remove the mushrooms by hand, especially before they release spores. Regularly mowing the lawn will also help manage their numbers. Ensure that you handle the mushrooms with care, as they are often mistaken for other potentially harmful species. Dispose of them safely to limit spore spread, if desired."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Mower's Mushroom","description":"Panaeolus foenisecii, commonly called the mower's mushroom, haymaker or brown hay mushroom, is a very common and widely distributed little brown mushroom often found on lawns. In many field guides it is erroneously listed as psychoactive, however the mushroom does not produce any hallucingenic effects.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":[],"other_name":["Mower's Mushroom"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["January"],"scientific_name":["Panaeolus foenisecii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18373,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Craterellus tubaeformis, commonly known as the Funnel Chanterelle, is a type of mushroom rather than a plant that requires specific conditions for optimal growth. As a fungi growing in moist forest environments, it does not need manual watering like plants but requires a habitat with high humidity. In cultivation, ensure the substrate is kept damp but not waterlogged, mimicking its natural forest floor environment. Over-saturation can lead to decay or mold, so good drainage is vital. Watering should mimic natural rainfall cycles, allowing the surface to dry slightly between waterings, which helps prevent fungal diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Craterellus tubaeformis thrives in shaded or partially shaded environments typical of forest floors. Direct sunlight can dry out the substrate, reducing humidity levels vital for its growth. When cultivating Funnel Chanterelles, replicate their natural habitat by providing plenty of indirect, dappled light, or a consistently shaded part of your garden. The environment should be cool and moist, as these mushrooms favor temperate climates with high humidity. Shield them from harsh sunlight and wind, which can desiccate the mushrooms and hinder their development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning isnât a traditional care practice for fungi like Craterellus tubaeformis, but it involves careful harvesting. These mushrooms should be gently twisted or cut at the stemâs base when collecting, ensuring not to damage the mycelium network below. This allows the fungi to continue growing and producing more fruiting bodies in the future. Removing debris and other competing vegetation around the mushrooms can promote healthy growth. This is less about pruning and more about maintaining optimal growth conditions, allowing the fungi to flourish without hindrance from competitors."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Yellowfoot","description":"Craterellus tubaeformis (formerly Cantharellus tubaeformis) is an edible fungus, also known as Yellowfoot, winter mushroom, or Funnel Chanterelle. It is mycorrhizal, forming symbiotic associations with plants, making it very challenging to cultivate. It is smaller than the golden chanterelle (Cantharellus cibarius) and has a dark brown cap with paler gills and a hollow yellow stem. C. tubaeformis tastes stronger but less fruity than the golden chanterelle. It has a very distinctive smokey, peppery taste when raw....","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America","Europe"],"other_name":["Yellowfoot"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Craterellus tubaeformis"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18771,"attracts":["Insects"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pterostylis banksii, commonly known as the Greenhood Orchid, prefers moderately moist conditions. During its active growing period in winter and spring, ensure the soil remains consistently moist but not waterlogged. Use a well-draining potting mix to prevent root rot. Reduce watering in late spring when the plant enters dormancy, allowing the soil to dry out slightly between waterings. In summer, when the plant is not actively growing, keep it drier but do not allow the soil to become completely parched. Monitor humidity and adjust watering accordingly to maintain optimal conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pterostylis banksii thrives in conditions that mimic its native woodland habitats. It should be placed in a spot where it receives bright but indirect sunlight to prevent scorching. Ideally, it should receive light dappled by a sheer curtain or shaded by taller plants. Direct sunlight, especially during noon, can be too intense and cause damage. If natural light is insufficient, especially in winter months, supplement with artificial grow lights set to simulate the natural day length without intense heat, ensuring the plant receives adequate light for healthy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not typically necessary for Pterostylis banksii, as it is a small, herbaceous orchid. However, you can remove any dead or yellowing leaves to improve the plant's appearance and prevent disease. The spikes from which the flowers emerge can be cut back to the base once they have finished blooming and begun to wither. This will help the plant focus its energy on growth and future flower production. Be sure to use clean, sharp tools to prevent any damage or disease transmission."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Tutukiwi","description":"Pterostylis banksii, commonly known as greenhood or tutukiwi, is a species of orchid endemic to New Zealand. Non-flowering plants have a rosette of leaves. Flowering plants have leaves on the flowering stem, some of which reach above the single relatively large, green flower with translucent white stripes. It is the most common, widespread and largest New Zealand greenhood and is found on both of the main islands.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["Tutukiwi"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids"],"propagation":["Division","Tissue Culture"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Pterostylis banksii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

If grown in low-light conditions, it is vital to move them occasionally to a brighter spot to boost their health temporarily."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Dracaena sanderiana involves trimming the stalk and removing any dead or yellowing leaves to maintain its aesthetic appeal and encourage healthy growth. Pruning should be done regularly to manage the plant's height and shape. Any cut leaves or stems can be propagated in water to grow new plants."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Lucky Bamboo","description":"Dracaena sanderiana is a species of flowering plant in the family Asparagaceae, also known as Dracaena braunii. At the end of the flowering season, you can cut back the foliage to tidy up the plant, but ensure some leaves remain to feed the bulb. It is important to ensure that the soil does not dry out completely between waterings. During its active growth period in spring and early summer, increase watering frequency, keeping the soil evenly moist but not waterlogged to avoid root rot. In the dormant period, usually in late summer or fall, reduce watering slightly but still maintain moisture. To determine when it's time to water, check the top inch of soil; if it feels dry to the touch, it's time to water. Avoid overhead watering to prevent fungal diseases on the leaves."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Viola uniflora enjoys partial shade to full sun conditions, but it typically thrives best in locations where it receives morning sun and afternoon shade, mimicking its natural woodland habitat. Too much direct, harsh midday sunlight can scorch the leaves, so if it's planted in a full sun location, ensure that it is protected during the peak sun hours. In particularly hot climates, additional shade is beneficial. Ensure that the location also has good air circulation to prevent mildew if planted in shadier settings. Observing the plant's growth will help you determine if it needs more or less light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Viola uniflora is minimal and primarily involves removing dead or damaged leaves to maintain plant health and improve air circulation. After the flowering period, spent blooms should be removed to encourage further blooming and prevent seed formation, which can sap energy from the plant. Annual maintenance pruning is usually carried out in early spring to tidy up the plant before its growth spurt. Trim any foliage that appears ragged or discolored. Be sure to use clean, sharp tools to prevent diseases and provide neat cuts close to the base without damaging the base or surrounding healthy leaves."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Siberian Violet","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Asia","North America"],"other_name":["Siberian Violet"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Viola uniflora"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Prune during the growing season, typically in spring or early summer. Avoid cutting off new growth tips, as this can inhibit the plant's ability to develop new fronds."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Shiny fan fern","description":"Sticherus flabellatus is a small fern found in eastern Australia and in New Zealand northwards from the north-west of the South Island. Watering should be done in moderation; the substrate or growing medium should be kept moist but not overly saturated. Misting the environment or using a humidity tent can help maintain the moisture levels necessary for growth. Ensure that there is good air circulation to prevent excessive humidity which can lead to mold or other fungal infections."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lentinus sajor-caju mushrooms thrive in low-light conditions, akin to their natural habitats in shaded, forested areas. They require diffused or indirect lighting rather than direct sunlight, which can dry out the growing medium and harm the delicate mushrooms. A location with filtered light or a controlled environment with grow lights simulating the forest understory conditions is ideal. If grown indoors, placing them in a well-ventilated room with ambient light or under fluorescent grow lights will support their photosensitive nature and enhance their growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Unlike traditional plants, Lentinus sajor-caju does not require pruning in the conventional sense. However, it is important to regularly harvest the mature mushrooms to encourage continuous growth. Harvesting is done when the mushrooms have reached their desired size and before the caps open too wide. This is typically when the edges of the caps curve slightly inward, and the gills are still pale. Removing mature mushrooms also helps prevent them from rotting on the substrate, which can affect the growth environment and potentially inhibit further development."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Funnel Woodcap","description":"Lentinus sajor-caju (formerly known as Pleurotus sajor-caju) is a species of saprophytic mushroom.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Asia"],"other_name":["Funnel Woodcap"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Lentinus sajor-caju"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is a drought-tolerant plant that prefers to dry out completely between waterings. During the growing season, typically spring and summer, water thoroughly but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings. In contrast, during the winter dormant period, reduce watering significantly, providing just enough moisture to prevent the plant from shriveling. Avoid letting water sit on the surface of the cactus, as this can cause rot. Overwatering is the most common issue, so it's better to underwater than overwater this cactus."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Epithelantha greggii thrives in bright light conditions and requires full sunlight to maintain its compact, healthy growth. In hotter climates, it may benefit from some afternoon shade to prevent scorching. Monitor the plant for signs of too much or too little light, adjusting its position as necessary. Adequate sunlight exposure ensures the cactus remains vibrant and supports its flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Epithelantha greggii requires minimal pruning, as it naturally maintains a compact and spherical shape. Pruning is generally unnecessary, but you can remove any dead or damaged sections to promote a healthier appearance. If the cactus produces pups or offsets, you may wish to separate them to encourage growth or propagation. Use sterilized tools to prevent infection. After pruning or removing offsets, allow the wounded areas to callous over before returning the plant to its original watering schedule. It is important to avoid both overwatering, which can lead to root rot, and letting the soil dry out completely, as this can harm the plant. Reducing watering frequency during dormancy in summer can mimic its natural environment, preserving the plant's health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Corybas macranthus thrives in low to moderate light conditions, mimicking its natural understory habitat in forests where it receives dappled light. A north-facing window or a spot away from the window is ideal. Providing the right amount of light will help maintain healthy foliage and encourage the production of flowers during the blooming season."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Corybas macranthus generally involves only the removal of spent flowers or damaged leaves, as orchids do not require significant pruning compared to other plants. Dead leaves can also be pruned to improve airflow and reduce the risk of disease. Since these orchids are sensitive, care should be taken to use sterilized scissors or shears to prevent disease transmission."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Silver-back Spider-Orchid","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["Australia","New Zealand"],"other_name":["Silver-back Spider-Orchid"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spots"],"propagation":["Division","Tissue Culture"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Corybas macranthus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Water the plant when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. Avoid letting the plant dry out completely between waterings, especially during its active growing season in spring and summer. In the winter, reduce the amount of water slightly as the plant's growth slows down. Be mindful of the drainage as the plant does not tolerate soggy soil, which could lead to root rot. Always use well-draining soil and pots with drainage holes to ensure proper water dispersal."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Dianthus superbus thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth and flowering. It can tolerate partial shade but may produce fewer flowers if not grown in full sun. When planting this perennial, choose a location that receives plenty of sunlight throughout the day. In regions with very hot summers, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent scorching. Indoors, place the plant near a south or west-facing window where it can enjoy bright, indirect light, ensuring it receives enough light to maintain its vibrant blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Dianthus superbus is essential to encourage healthy growth and abundant flowering. Regularly deadhead spent blossoms by cutting them off at the base to prolong the blooming period and prevent the plant from diverting energy into seed production. In late fall, after the plant has finished blooming, cut back the stems to about one-third of their original height to tidy up the appearance and promote new growth in the spring. If desired, you can also trim back any dead or damaged foliage throughout the growing season to maintain the plant's overall vigor and health."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Fringed Pink","description":"Dianthus superbus (fringed pink or large pink) is a species of Dianthus native to Europe and northern Asia, from northernmost Spain and France north to arctic Norway, and east to Japan; in the south of its range, it occurs at high altitudes, up to 2,400 m.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Fringed Pink"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Dianthus superbus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19469,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Diosma hirsuta, also known as 'Hairy Buchu,' enjoys moist conditions but is susceptible to root rot if overwatered. Water deeply once the top inch of soil feels dry, ensuring good drainage to prevent waterlogging. In hotter climates or during summer, increase watering frequency compared to cooler months. Mulching the base can help retain moisture and reduce watering needs, but avoid letting water sit on the leaves for extended periods, as this can cause fungal issues. Adjust watering frequency based on specific environmental conditions and growth stage, avoiding drought stress."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Diosma hirsuta thrives in full sun to partial shade. It requires at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily to promote flowering and maintain compact growth. In very hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can protect it from intense heat. If the plant starts becoming leggy or sparse, it may indicate insufficient light, and you should consider relocating it to a sunnier spot. Indoors, place the plant near a south or west-facing window to ensure it receives adequate bright light, which is essential for its flowering and overall health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Diosma hirsuta should be done to maintain a compact and bushy shape and to encourage new growth. After flowering, lightly prune the plant, cutting back to a leaf node, to prevent it from becoming straggly. Remove dead or damaged branches throughout the year to maintain its health. Avoid cutting into old wood, as this can inhibit regrowth. Regularly clip off spent flowers to promote continued blooming and to keep the plant looking tidy. Use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts for the best results, helping to prevent disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Common Bitterbuchu","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Common Bitterbuchu"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Diosma hirsuta"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19862,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Oenothera simulans, like many in its genus, prefers well-draining soil and does not like to be waterlogged. Water the plant deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. During the growing season (spring and summer), water the plant once a week, depending on rainfall and humidity levels. In the winter, reduce watering to once every two weeks or less, as the plant enters dormancy and requires less moisture. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure that your pot or garden bed has adequate drainage."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Oenothera simulans thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth and flowering. It can tolerate partial shade, but this may reduce its blooming potential. Plant it in a location where it receives morning sunlight and some afternoon shade if you are in a particularly hot climate. This will help prevent the leaves from scorching. Ensure that it is not overshadowed by larger plants or structures, as adequate sunlight is crucial for its photosynthesis and overall health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Oenothera simulans is primarily aimed at encouraging healthy growth and enhancing blooming. Trim back the stems after the flowers have faded, cutting them down to the base foliage to encourage a fuller growth habit and potentially a second bloom. Remove any dead or damaged leaves during the growing season to prevent disease. In the fall, it's beneficial to cut the plant back to the ground as it goes dormant, which will help rejuvenate the plant for the next season. Avoid heavy pruning during its active growing season in spring and summer."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Southern Beeblossom","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Southern Beeblossom"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Oenothera simulans"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

The key purpose for pruning is to remove any dead or dying leaves and spent flowers to promote healthy growth and to prevent disease. Water the plant when the top inch of the soil feels dry to the touch. During the hotter months or when the plant is actively growing, you may need to water more frequently, at least once a week. It's important to avoid letting the plant completely dry out or sit in waterlogged soil as both can cause stress or damage to the root system."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Christella parasitica thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. Direct sunlight can scorch the fronds, leading to browning, while too little light can slow its growth and reduce leaf color intensity. Ideally, place this plant in a location where it can receive filtered light, such as near a north or east-facing window. It can tolerate some lower light conditions, but you'll see the best growth when it receives enough bright, indirect sun. Ensure any artificial lighting mimics this natural setting if grown indoors."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Christella parasitica involves removing any dead or damaged fronds which can be done at any time of the year. This helps maintain the plant's health and appearance. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to cut the fronds back to their base without damaging nearby healthy fronds. Regular pruning will also encourage new growth by ensuring that the plantâs energy is directed towards healthy parts. Be cautious not to over-prune, as this can stress the plant and reduce its overall vitality."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Parasitic Tri-vein Fern","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Southeast Asia","Australia","Africa"],"other_name":["Parasitic Tri-vein Fern"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Sporus propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Christella parasitica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19071,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Erythranthe guttata, commonly known as the monkey flower, typically thrives in moist environments. Water this plant regularly to maintain consistently damp soil, but ensure good drainage to prevent waterlogging. It prefers growing near streams or moist areas, and frequent watering replicates its natural habitat. The soil should not be allowed to dry out completely, especially during its growing season. During colder months when growth slows, reduce frequency slightly, but still aim to keep the soil moist. Monitor the plant regularly, as its moisture needs can be higher in warm weather."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Erythranthe guttata prefers partial to full sunlight, replicating its natural habitat of open, sunny areas near water sources. Ideally, it should receive morning sun and be shaded during the intense afternoon rays to prevent scorching. In very hot climates, partial shade can help protect it from excessive heat, while in cooler regions, it may tolerate more direct sunlight. Adjust its light exposure based on your local climate, ensuring it receives at least 4-6 hours of sunlight daily for optimal growth. Indoors or in shaded gardens, consider supplementing with artificial grow lights if necessary."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Erythranthe guttata involves removing spent flowers and dead or damaged leaves to encourage healthy growth and prolong flowering. This can be done throughout the growing season. Deadheading, or pinching off wilted blooms, helps stimulate new blooms. In early spring, a more thorough pruning can be done to remove any lingering dead stems and leaves from the previous season. Pruning can also help keep the plant tidy and control its size, especially if it starts to spread too vigorously. Always use clean, sharp instruments to avoid damaging the plant or introducing disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"seep monkeyflower","description":"Erythranthe guttata, with the common names seep monkeyflower and common yellow monkeyflower, is a yellow bee-pollinated annual or perennial plant. It was formerly known as Mimulus guttatus.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["seep monkeyflower"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Erythranthe guttata"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18178,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Trifolium alpestre, commonly known as red feather clover, prefers moderately moist conditions but is relatively drought-tolerant once established. It is important to avoid over-watering, as this can lead to root rot. Ideally, water the plant thoroughly once the soil's top inch feels dry, ensuring adequate drainage. During periods of extended drought, increase the frequency of watering to maintain soil moisture at a consistent level. In their natural habitat, these plants often rely on rainwater, so mimicking this condition can support healthy growth. Adjust watering frequency according to the plantâs growth cycle and climate conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Trifolium alpestre thrives in full sun to partial shade environments. For optimal growth and flowering, provide at least six hours of direct sunlight daily. While the plant can tolerate partial shade, less sunlight may result in reduced flowering and less vigorous growth. In hotter climates or during the peak summer months, providing some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch and stress. In higher altitudes or cooler regions, maximizing sunlight exposure will help the plant reach its full potential. Aim to plant Trifolium alpestre in a location that balances direct sunlight with shelter from extreme midday heat."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Trifolium alpestre is generally minimal but can contribute to healthier growth and increased flowering potential. Regularly deadhead spent flowers to encourage continuous blooming and prevent the plant from going to seed too early. Additionally, trim back any dead or damaged foliage to maintain plant vitality and appearance. At the end of the growing season, cut the plant back to about half its size to protect it during the winter months and to promote a vigorous regrowth in the spring. Pruning helps manage size and shape, particularly in garden settings where space is a concern."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"alpine zigzag clover","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["alpine zigzag clover"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Trifolium alpestre"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18473,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cuphophyllus pratensis, commonly known as the meadow waxcap, is usually found in damp grasslands. When cultivated in similar conditions, it generally requires consistent moisture to mimic its natural habitat. However, overwatering should be avoided to prevent root rot. Watering should be done so that the soil remains consistently moist but not waterlogged. It's usually best to water it deeply but infrequently, allowing the top layer of soil to dry out slightly between waterings. This approach helps in maintaining the balanced moisture level the plant needs to thrive."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cuphophyllus pratensis is often found in open meadows and grasslands, where it receives ample sunlight. In cultivation, it thrives best in partial to full sun exposure, preferably in an environment that replicates its natural habitat. Ensure it receives at least a few hours of direct sunlight each day while avoiding excessive exposure, particularly in very hot regions, to prevent dehydration of the soil and damage to the organism. Balancing light exposure is key to encouraging healthy growth and maintaining the natural vibrancy of these waxcaps."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not usually necessary for Cuphophyllus pratensis, as this is a type of mushroom rather than a traditional plant with branches and leaves that require pruning. However, maintaining its growing area by removing debris or decaying plant material can be beneficial. If you're cultivating these mushrooms, focus on maintaining soil health and cleanliness to allow optimal growth. Also, consider removing any darker or faded mushrooms to encourage new growth, but typically the environment rather than pruning itself dictates its health and development."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Meadow Waxcap","description":"Cuphophyllus pratensis is a species of agaric (gilled mushroom) in the family Hygrophoraceae. It has been given the recommended English name of meadow waxcap in the UK and in North America has variously been called the meadow waxy cap, salmon waxy cap, and butter meadowcap. The species has a widespread, mainly temperate distribution, occurring in grassland in Europe and in woodland elsewhere. The basidiocarps (fruit bodies) are edible and are occasionally collected and sold commercially.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America","Europe"],"other_name":["Meadow Waxcap"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Cuphophyllus pratensis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
