{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18976,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Vicia unijuga, commonly known as the two-leaved vetch, prefers a moderate watering schedule. It is important to maintain a consistently moist soil without allowing it to become waterlogged, as excessive moisture can lead to root rot. During the growing season, ensure the soil remains damp by watering regularly when the top inch becomes dry. In contrast, reduce the watering frequency during the plant's dormant period in colder months. Mulching can help retain moisture and reduce the frequency of watering needed, particularly in hotter weather."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Vicia unijuga thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, the plant should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight each day to promote healthy growth and flowering. However, it can tolerate some shade, especially in regions with hot, intense midday sun. In such cases, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent the plant from becoming scorched. If grown indoors or in a greenhouse, ensure the plant receives sufficient indirect sunlight by placing it near a bright window or supplementing with grow lights if necessary."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Vicia unijuga involves the removal of dead or damaged stems to encourage healthy growth. Early spring is an ideal time for pruning, just before new growth begins. Cut back any overgrown or tangled vines to maintain a tidy appearance and to encourage bushier foliage. Regular deadheading, or removing spent flowers, can prevent seed formation and promote a longer blooming period. Additionally, thinning out crowded areas will increase air circulation around the plant, minimizing the risk of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Two-leaf Vetch","description":"Vicia unijuga, commonly called two-leaf vetch, is a species of flowering plant in the legume family.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["China","Japan","Korea"],"other_name":["Two-leaf Vetch"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Vicia unijuga"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18276,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Serapias cordigera, like many orchids, requires careful watering to thrive. It is essential to keep the soil medium slightly moist during the growing season from autumn to late spring. Water the plant once a week or when the top inch of the soil feels dry. Ensure proper drainage as waterlogged conditions can lead to root rot. During its dormant summer phase, reduce watering significantly, allowing the plant to dry out more between waterings. Mist the plant lightly during very hot or dry conditions to maintain humidity, which supports healthy growth during its active phases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Serapias cordigera thrives in environments that offer bright indirect sunlight. While direct sunlight can be too intense and may scorch the leaves, a bright position with filtered light is ideal. If grown indoors, placing the plant near an east or west-facing window where it can receive a few hours of gentle morning or late afternoon sun is perfect. Outdoors, position the plant in partial shade to mimic its natural habitat. During the hottest part of the day, ensure it is protected from the sharp midday sun to prevent leaf burns and stress on the plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Serapias cordigera is generally minimal but necessary to maintain plant health. Remove spent flowers after they have wilted to encourage further blooming and prevent the plant from wasting energy on seed production. Cut the flower spikes close to the base using clean, sharp pruning shears to avoid infection. After the growing season ends and the leaves naturally begin to wither, trim back the dried foliage to facilitate new growth in the following season. Regular inspection for any diseased or dead material should also be conducted and removed promptly."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Heart-flowered serapias","description":"Serapias cordigera is a species of orchids found from the Azores, south-central Europe to the Mediterranean.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mediterranean","Southern Europe"],"other_name":["Heart-flowered serapias"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Serapias cordigera"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18872,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Aechmea fasciata, also known as the Urn Plant, thrives with moderate watering. It is essential to keep the central cup, or rosette, partially filled with water at all times, as this is its primary hydration method in the wild. Use rainwater or distilled water to avoid mineral build-up. Allow the soil to dry slightly between waterings, usually watering every 1-2 weeks, depending on the environment's humidity and temperature. Avoid overwatering, which can lead to root rot. Mist the leaves occasionally to maintain humidity, especially in dry indoor conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Aechmea fasciata prefers bright, indirect sunlight. Direct sunlight should be avoided as it can scorch the leaves. Place the plant near a window with filtered light or in a location where it receives dappled sunlight for optimal growth. In limited light conditions, such as north-facing rooms, the plant may not flower as profusely but will still grow. During the darker winter months, additional fluorescent grow lights can supplement natural light. Ideal temperatures range from 60Â°F to 80Â°F (15Â°C to 27Â°C), as the plant is not frost-tolerant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Aechmea fasciata involves removing dead or damaged leaves to maintain the plant's appearance and health. Carefully trim away any brown or wilting leaves at the base using a clean pair of scissors or pruning shears. This helps prevent disease and pest issues by improving air circulation. Once the plant finishes flowering, the old flower spike can be cut close to its base. Over time, the mother plant will produce offsets or pups, which can be separated for propagation once they reach a third of the parent plant's size. Minimal pruning is generally required beyond these steps."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Urn Plant","description":"Aechmea fasciata (silver vase, urn plant) is a species of flowering plant in the bromeliad family, native to Brazil. This plant is probably the best known species in this genus, and it is often grown as a houseplant in temperate areas. It has gained the Royal Horticultural Society's Award of Garden Merit.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Brazil"],"other_name":["Urn Plant"],"pest_susceptibility":["Mealybugs","Scale insects"],"propagation":["Offset Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Aechmea fasciata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19765,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Aphyllon uniflorum, commonly known as One-flowered Broomrape, is a parasitic plant that generally does not require traditional watering, as it derives water and nutrients from its host plant. However, ensuring the host plant receives adequate water will indirectly benefit Aphyllon uniflorum. If cultivated or observed in pots, maintain a moderately moist soil around the host plant without allowing it to become waterlogged. Avoid overwatering, which can harm both the host and related parasitic plants."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Aphyllon uniflorum requires indirect sunlight, primarily dictated by the needs of its host plant. Generally, it will thrive in locations where the host plant is suited, focusing on areas with partial shade. Direct sunlight may be detrimental if it overheats or dries out the host. Therefore, positioning the plant where it can receive light filtered through foliage or during the cooler parts of the day can help maintain the needed balance. Ensure the conditions mimic its natural habitat to encourage healthy development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Since Aphyllon uniflorum is a parasitic plant, it typically does not require pruning as traditional plants do. Pruning is unnecessary for its growth, as it depends on the host plant's health and vigor. However, if managing it for conservation or study, one might carefully remove dead or dying stems to prevent any potential disease spread. Always be cautious not to damage the plant or its host while handling it, as its health is closely tied to that of the host."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"one-flowered cancer-root","description":"Orobanche uniflora, commonly known as one-flowered broomrape, one-flowered cancer root, ghost pipe or naked broomrape, is an annual parasitic herbaceous plant. The \"broom\" might refer to the plant's shape while \"rape\" might refer to the lumps that are on its roots. It is native to much of North America, where it is a parasitic plant, tapping nutrients from many other species of plants, including those in the families Asteraceae and Saxifragaceae and in the genus Sedum....","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["one-flowered cancer-root"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Aphyllon uniflorum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

If you observe elongated stems, it may indicate insufficient light, prompting a move to a brighter spot."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Crassula moschata involves removing any dead or unhealthy foliage to encourage new growth and maintain a tidy appearance. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19072,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Melanolepis multiglandulosa prefers soil that is consistently moist but not waterlogged. Water the plant regularly, ensuring that the topsoil does not dry out entirely. However, avoid excessive watering, which can lead to root rot. It's ideal to water thoroughly once the top inch of soil feels dry. During peak growing seasons, such as spring and summer, you may need to increase the frequency of watering. In contrast, during the cooler months, reduce the watering schedule as the plant's growth slows down. Always adjust watering based on the humidity and temperature of your local climate."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Melanolepis multiglandulosa thrives in full to partial sunlight. Ideally, the plant should receive several hours of direct sunlight each day to grow healthily. In regions with intense sunlight, particularly in the afternoon, partial shade can help prevent leaf scorch. During the plant's active growing season, ensure it has adequate light exposure to promote vigorous growth and flowering. However, in extremely hot climates, providing some shelter from the harshest midday sun can benefit the plant. If growing indoors, a bright spot near a window with good sunlight is recommended."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Melanolepis multiglandulosa should be done sparingly and strategically to maintain its natural shape and health. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches as soon as they are noticed to prevent infections. If the plant becomes too dense, thin out the older branches to improve air circulation and light penetration. Major pruning tasks are best done in the late winter or early spring before the plant begins its active growth phase. Always use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts that will heal quickly. Regular light pruning can help manage size and encourage bushier growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Alim","description":"Melanolepsis multiglandulosa is a plant species of the family Euphorbiaceae, first described in 1826. It is native to Nansei-shoto, Mariana Islands, Solomon Islands, Bismarck Archipelago, New Guinea, Maluku, Sulawesi, Philippines, Lesser Sunda Islands, Java, Sumatra, Borneo, Thailand, Malaysia and Taiwan.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Spring","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Southeast Asia","Pacific Islands"],"other_name":["Alim"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Melanolepis multiglandulosa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18379,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lactifluus hygrophoroides, commonly known as a type of mushroom rather than a typical houseplant, doesnât require traditional watering as itâs a naturally occurring fungi in the wild. Instead, if you are growing this mushroom for cultivation or study purposes, it's important to maintain a high humidity environment. This can be done by misting regularly or using a humidifier to keep the environment damp, imitating the natural, moisture-rich habitats where these mushrooms thrive, such as damp leaf litter in deciduous forests."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lactifluus hygrophoroides tends to grow in shaded, forested environments with dappled sunlight. When cultivating this mushroom indoors, direct sunlight is not necessary. Instead, provide indirect light or maintain them in low-light conditions to mimic their natural habitat. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18873,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Porphyrellus formosus, being a mycorrhizal mushroom found in woodlands, is not a plant and thus does not require typical watering like houseplants. The environmental moisture of its natural habitat, which includes damp forest floors, is crucial for its growth. Replicating this environment, such as in a terrarium or a controlled outdoor space, would mean maintaining a consistently humid atmosphere rather than direct watering. Ensure the growing medium is moist but not waterlogged, simulating the forest floor conditions where natural rainfall and decomposing matter provide the necessary moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Porphyrellus formosus naturally thrives in shaded woodland environments where direct sunlight is limited. In cultivation, mimic these conditions by providing dappled or indirect sunlight, similar to what is found beneath a forest canopy. While keeping them completely out of direct sun is critical to prevent drying out and damage, a location that receives filtered light is ideal. If growing indoors, placing them near a north-facing window or providing shade with sheer curtains can help replicate the gentle, diffuse light conditions necessary for their development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable to Porphyrellus formosus as it is a type of fungus rather than a plant. Fungi do not grow foliage or branches that require trimming. However, if cultivating these mushrooms, it is important to regularly harvest the fruiting bodies by carefully cutting them at the base once they reach maturity, which helps in maintaining the health of the organism and encourages further fruiting. Ensure to also remove any old or decaying mushrooms to prevent mold and pests from developing in the area."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Dark Velvet Bolete","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"High","origin":[],"other_name":["Dark Velvet Bolete"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Porphyrellus formosus"],"soil":["Humus rich","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18778,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Raoulia glabra, commonly known as a type of New Zealand mat plant, requires minimal watering once established. It thrives in well-drained soil and is naturally adapted to dry conditions. During its active growing season in spring and early summer, water the plant moderately, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's crucial to ensure good drainage. In winter, water sparingly as the plant is dormant and requires less moisture. Always adjust watering based on rainfall and humidity, especially in its natural alpine habitat."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Raoulia glabra requires full sun to thrive and develop its characteristic silvery appearance. It is well-suited for rock gardens where sunlight is abundant. This alpine plant is accustomed to high light conditions in its native habitat, which helps it maintain its compact, mat-like form. When planted in partial shade, it may become leggy and lose its compact growth habit. Ensure it receives at least six hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth and health. If growing indoors or in less sunny areas, supplement with grow lights to mimic natural conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Raoulia glabra is generally minimal and primarily involves maintaining the plantâs shape and removing any dead or damaged growth. In early spring, before the growing season begins, inspect the plant and prune any dead or diseased areas using sharp, clean shears. This not only improves the plantâs appearance but also promotes healthy new growth. Avoid cutting too deeply into the central parts of the plant, as this can inhibit its growth. Regularly check for any spreading or overcrowding, especially if planted in a rock garden, to ensure it has ample space to grow."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Smooth Mat Daisy","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Silver-gray"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["Smooth Mat Daisy"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Raoulia glabra"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19864,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Reynoutria multiflora, commonly known as Chinese knotweed or He Shou Wu, prefers consistently moist soil, but it should not be waterlogged. Water the plant when the top inch of soil begins to feel dry to the touch. Infrequent, deep watering sessions are preferable over frequent shallow watering, as this encourages the roots to grow deeper and makes the plant more resilient to drought. During the growing season in spring and summer, you may need to water more frequently, whereas in the dormant winter months, reduce watering considerably to prevent root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Reynoutria multiflora grows best in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight each day. In regions with very intense summer sunlight, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent scorching of the foliage. If grown in too much shade, the plant may become leggy and will not produce as many flowers. This plant is adaptable, but ensuring adequate sunlight will promote vigorous growth and optimal blooming. It's important to monitor the plantâs placement to adjust sunlight exposure as needed."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning offers several benefits for Reynoutria multiflora, including maintaining its shape and promoting healthy growth. Ideally, you should prune this plant in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Use clean, sharp pruners to remove dead, damaged, or diseased stems. If the plant appears overgrown, thinning out some of the older, woody stems can encourage new growth. Prune back to a healthy bud or the base of the plant. Regular pruning prevents the plant from becoming too leggy and helps control its spread, as it can be quite vigorous."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"tuber fleeceflower","description":"Reynoutria multiflora (synonyms Fallopia multiflora and Polygonum multiflorum) is a species of flowering plant in the buckwheat family Polygonaceae. It is known as tuber fleeceflower and Chinese knotweed. It is native to central and southern China.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["China","Japan","Korea","Taiwan"],"other_name":["tuber fleeceflower"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Powdery mildew","Aphids"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Reynoutria multiflora"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Clay"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18978,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pyrrosia adnascens, like many ferns, prefers consistently moist conditions. Water the plant thoroughly whenever the top one inch of soil feels dry to the touch. It's important to avoid letting the plant sit in water, so ensure good drainage to prevent root rot. In warmer months, you may need to water it more frequently, while in cooler months, the frequency can be reduced. Using distilled or rainwater is ideal, as tap water can sometimes contain salts and chemicals that might harm the fern."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pyrrosia adnascens thrives in bright, indirect light. Direct sunlight can scorch the leaves, so it's best to place the fern in a location where it receives filtered light or partial shade. Ensure the plant is not in deep shade for extended periods, as this could lead to weak growth and reduced vigor."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Pyrrosia adnascens is generally minimal, mainly to remove dead or yellowing leaves. This helps to keep the plant looking tidy and promotes new growth. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to prevent damage and disease spread. Make cuts close to the base of the leaf to maintain a neat appearance. Regularly inspecting and removing any affected foliage can help keep the plant healthy and vigorous. There is no need for drastic pruning with this fern, as it naturally maintains a pleasing shape."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Tongue-fern","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Asia","Australia"],"other_name":["Tongue-fern"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Pyrrosia adnascens"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18278,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Typha orientalis, also known as bulrush, is a perennial aquatic plant that thrives in wet, marshy areas. It prefers consistently wet conditions and can tolerate both fresh and slightly brackish water. For optimal growth, ensure the soil or substrate is kept consistently moist. This plant is well-suited for the edges of ponds or water gardens where it can access a steady supply of water. Be cautious not to let the plant dry out, as it relies on abundant moisture to maintain health and vigor. If grown in pots, consider placing them in water-filled saucers or submerging them partway in a water feature."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Typha orientalis thrives in full sunlight conditions for optimal growth and flowering. It requires at least six hours of direct sunlight daily to maintain its vigorous growth and produce healthy foliage and robust flower spikes. While it can tolerate partial shade, the plant may not grow as vigorously or produce as many flowers. In areas that experience intense, scorching midday sun, providing some shade during the hottest part of the day can prevent leaf burn. Ensuring that Typha orientalis has access to ample sunlight will support its overall health and aesthetic appeal in a garden setting."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Typha orientalis involves removing old, brown, or damaged leaves to encourage new growth and improve the plant's appearance. Prune back the dead stems to just above the plant base in late winter or early spring before the new growth begins. This timing helps to prevent disease and provides a tidier look. Additionally, removing flower heads before they set seed can help control the spread, especially since Typha orientalis can be quite vigorous and form large colonies if left unchecked. During its growing season in the fall and winter, keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent rot. In the dormant summer months, reduce watering significantly, letting the soil dry out completely between watering sessions. Overwatering during dormancy should be avoided to maintain plant health. Using a well-draining soil will help prevent water retention that can lead to root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Baeometra uniflora thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. It prefers a well-lit position that receives at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial, especially during the peak of summer, to prevent the leaves from scorching. Insufficient sunlight can lead to sparse blooms and leggy growth. When planted in partial shade, ensure that it still receives a few hours of direct sunlight to maintain its vibrant appearance and encourage abundant flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Baeometra uniflora is generally minimal as the plant maintains a compact growth habit. Remove spent flowers to encourage prolonged blooming and prevent the plant from using its energy for seed production. Trim away any yellow or dead foliage at the base to keep the plant tidy and healthy. This can be done as needed throughout its growing season. Avoid aggressive pruning, as it is a bulbous plant that relies on its foliage for food storage after blooming has finished. Allow the foliage to naturally die back to nourish the bulb for the next season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Beetle Lily","description":"Baeometra is a genus in the family Colchicaceae containing a single species, Baeometra uniflora. It is native to South Africa, where it is commonly called beetle lily due to the dark markings on the tepals. The genus was erected when the British botanist Richard Salisbury described the species \"Baeometra columellaris\" in 1812, although the plant had already been discovered, described and painted in 1793 by the Austrian botanist Nikolaus Joseph von Jacquin under the name Melanthium...","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Beetle Lily"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Baeometra uniflora"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Therefore, it does not require traditional watering like terrestrial plants. However, if grown in a garden pond or container, ensure the water level is maintained to keep it submerged as it prefers shallow water conditions. If the water evaporates, particularly in hot weather, top up with fresh water to keep the plant healthy. Remember, maintaining a stable water condition is vital to prevent the plant from drying out and wilting."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ranunculus peltatus prefers full sun to partial shade for optimal growth. In its natural habitat, it usually grows in areas that receive ample sunlight throughout the day. Aligning its light exposure to these conditions will encourage healthy blooms and foliage. If cultivating in a garden pond, aim for an area that receives at least 4-6 hours of sunlight daily. While it can tolerate partial shade, insufficient light might lead to reduced flowering and less vigorous growth. Balancing direct sunlight and shade is crucial, especially in regions with intense summers."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ranunculus peltatus involves trimming away any dead or decaying foliage to maintain its health and appearance. Since it's an aquatic plant, check regularly for leaves that may be yellowing or decomposing due to prolonged submergence or lack of light. These should be carefully removed to prevent them from falling into the water and contributing to algae growth. Additionally, thinning out overcrowded plants can help increase air circulation and light penetration. When pruning, ensure to use clean, sharp tools to prevent the spread of any diseases."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Pond Water-crowfoot","description":"Ranunculus peltatus (Pond Water-crowfoot) is a plant species in the genus Ranunculus, native to Europe, southwestern Asia and northern Africa.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Pond Water-crowfoot"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Leaf miners"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Ranunculus peltatus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is essential to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Water deeply at the base of the plant about once a week, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. During hotter months or dry spells, increase the frequency to prevent the roots from drying out. It is best to water in the early morning or late afternoon to minimize evaporation and ensure the plant can absorb adequate moisture without the risk of fungal diseases that can occur with evening watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rosa glabrifolia thrives best in full sunlight, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal flowering and growth. Plant it in a location where it can receive morning sun and some afternoon shade, especially in hotter climates, to prevent leaf scorch. While it can tolerate partial shade, reduced sunlight may lead to fewer blooms and weaker growth. Ensuring it gets an adequate amount of light is crucial for its health and to maximize its beautiful floral display throughout the growing season."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rosa glabrifolia is important for maintaining its shape and encouraging healthy growth. Prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove dead or damaged wood first, followed by any crossed branches to improve air circulation. Cut back stems and branches to outward-facing buds to shape the plant. Regularly deadhead spent flowers during the growing season to promote continual blooming. Hard pruning can be done every couple of years to rejuvenate the plant, ensuring it remains vigorous and maintains a healthy framework."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Russian rose","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Russian rose"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Black spot","Powdery mildew","Rust"],"propagation":["Cutting","Grafting Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Rosa glabrifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It can tolerate some direct sunlight, especially in cooler climates, but too much direct exposure in hot climates can scorch the leaves. If grown indoors, placing the plant near a well-lit window where it receives filtered sunlight is ideal. For outdoor cultivation, choosing a spot that provides partial shade during the hottest part of the day will help keep the plant healthy. However, gradual acclimatization to the sun is recommended if moving the plant to a brighter location."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ficus racemosa is essential to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. Pruning should be done during its dormant season, which is usually in early spring or late winter. Dead or diseased branches should be removed immediately to prevent the spread of disease. Additionally, any crossing branches or branches that disrupt the treeâs natural form should be cut back. Regular pruning also helps increase air circulation within the foliage. Use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts and avoid causing undue stress to the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Cluster Fig","description":"Ficus racemosa (syn. Popularly known as the cluster fig tree, Indian fig tree or goolar (gular) fig, this is native to Australia, Malaysia, Southeast Asia and the Indian subcontinent. It is unusual in that its figs grow on or close to the tree trunk, termed cauliflory. In India, the tree and its fruit are called gular in the north and atti in the south....","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["India","Australia","Malaysia"],"other_name":["Cluster Fig"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Ficus racemosa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19471,"attracts":["birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Protea mundii prefers well-draining soil and does not like to sit in waterlogged conditions. Water the plant moderately, allowing the soil to dry out between watering sessions. During the growing season, increase watering frequency slightly but ensure the soil never becomes soggy. It is crucial to adjust watering based on environmental conditions such as temperature, humidity, and rainfall. Over-watering can lead to root rot, so itâs better to err on the side of under-watering with Proteas."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Protea mundii thrives in full sunlight and requires at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day. It can tolerate partial shade but may result in fewer blooms and a less robust plant. When positioning your plant, choose a location with plenty of natural light, such as a south-facing spot. Ensure the space is warm and sheltered from harsh wind, as a consistent sun exposure encourages strong growth and vibrant flowering. In less sunny climates, consider providing additional light sources indoors."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Protea mundii should be done to maintain its shape and encourage more prolific flowering. The best time to prune is after the flowering season ends. Remove spent flower heads and any dead or diseased branches. When pruning, cut just above a node or where the leaf pairs join. Take care not to prune too heavily, as Proteas grow new flowers on old wood. Removing too much can prevent flowering the following season. Light, regular pruning maintains a healthy plant structure."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Forest Sugarbush","description":"Protea mundii, the forest sugarbush, is a flowering shrub native to the Cape Provinces of South Africa, growing in forest margins at 200 to 1,300Â m (660 to 4,270Â ft) elevation. It grows to a height of 8Â m (26Â ft). The plant has white to ivory flowers, which are attractive to bees, butterflies and/or birds. The specific name commemorates Johannes Ludwig Leopold Mund, a German natural history collector who was active in the Cape until 1831.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Forest Sugarbush"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Protea mundii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18678,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Crassula pellucida, like many succulents, prefers to dry out between waterings. It is important to wait until the soil is completely dry before watering again to prevent root rot. During the growing season, typically spring through early fall, it may require watering every 1-2 weeks. In winter, reduce watering frequency to once a month, as the plant's water needs decrease during dormancy. Always ensure that the pot has drainage holes to prevent water from sitting in the soil."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Crassula pellucida thrives best in bright, indirect sunlight, though it can tolerate some direct sun. A location that provides about 4-6 hours of morning sun or dappled shade throughout the day is ideal. Too much direct sunlight, especially during the hottest part of the day, can scorch the leaves, while too little light may cause the plant to become leggy. If growing indoors, a south or east-facing window can provide the necessary light, but be sure to adjust based on the plant's response."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Crassula pellucida helps maintain its shape and encourages bushier growth. Use sharp, clean scissors or pruning shears to trim back leggy or dead stems. Pruning is best done in the spring or early summer, which is the plant's active growing period. Remove any leaves with signs of disease to prevent the spread and improve air circulation around the plant. Avoid excessive pruning, and focus on removing about one-third of the plant at a time for healthier rejuvenation."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Crystal Stonecrop","description":"Crassula pellucida is a creeping, succulent ground-cover, or low-growing, spreading succulent shrub, indigenous to South Africa.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Crystal Stonecrop"],"pest_susceptibility":["Mealybugs","Aphids"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Crassula pellucida"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19373,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Primula meadia, commonly known as the shooting star, prefers consistently moist soil. It thrives best in conditions where the soil is kept evenly moist, especially during its growing period in spring and early summer. Avoid letting the soil dry out completely, as this can stress the plant and hinder its growth, but be careful not to overwater, as soggy soil can lead to root rot. It might require more frequent watering during dry spells, especially when it's actively growing. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and regulate temperature."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Primula meadia prefers partial to full shade environments, especially in regions with hot summers. It thrives under dappled sunlight, as it imitates its natural woodland habitat. In northern climates, it can tolerate more direct sunlight but should be shielded from harsh afternoon sun. Too much direct sunlight can scorch the leaves and negatively affect the plant's health. In shaded areas, the soil tends to retain moisture better, which complements its preference for moist conditions. Adjust placement as needed to protect it from extreme sunlight exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Primula meadia is generally minimal. After the blooming period, you can deadhead the spent flowers to prevent the plant from spreading seeds excessively, unless natural propagation is desired. Cut back the stems to the base once flowering has completed to maintain the plantâs appearance and direct energy back to the roots. Additionally, remove any dead or damaged leaves to improve air circulation and reduce the risk of fungal diseases. Clean pruning tools with alcohol to prevent disease spread. This generally occurs in late spring to early summer."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"eastern shooting star","description":"Dodecatheon meadia is a species of flowering plant in the family Primulaceae, native to North America. It is found in the American South, as well as the Upper Midwest, Kansas, New York, Pennsylvania and the Canadian province of Manitoba. It grows in woods and prairies and tolerates partial shade.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["eastern shooting star"],"pest_susceptibility":["Slugs","Snails"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Primula meadia"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19577,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lanaria lanata requires moderate watering. It is essential to let the topsoil dry out slightly between waterings to avoid overwatering, which can harm the plant. During its active growing season, typically spring through summer, ensure the soil remains consistently moist but not soggy. During the dormant period in fall and winter, reduce watering frequency, allowing the plant to rest. It's crucial to use well-draining soil to prevent root rot caused by excessive moisture, and ensure any excess water is able to drain away promptly from the pot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lanaria lanata thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. It can tolerate filtered sunlight but should be protected from direct, harsh midday sun, which can scorch its leaves. Ideal locations include areas that receive morning sun or spots where the plant is exposed to diffused light through sheer curtains. If grown indoors, placing the plant near an east or west-facing window is preferable. However, ensure it does not sit too far from the light source to prevent leggy growth. Monitoring light exposure is key to maintaining the plant's health and vibrancy of blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lanaria lanata involves removing any dead or damaged foliage to promote healthy growth and improve the plant's appearance. This can be done as needed throughout the growing season. Additionally, after the flowering period, deadheading spent blooms can encourage further blooming and prevent the plant from expending energy on seed production. Use sterilized tools to make clean cuts, and avoid removing too much live tissue at once, which can stress the plant. Regular pruning also helps to prevent any pest or disease issues by allowing better air circulation around the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Lambstail","description":"Lanaria is a monotypic genus of flowering plants containing a single species, Lanaria lanata, endemic to the southern coast of South Africa where it is associated with the fynbos belt. Lanaria lanata is commonly known as Cape edelweiss or lambtails. The genus is placed in the monotypic family Lanariaceae, a family only recently recognized by taxonomists. The APG IV system of 2016 (unchanged from the 1998, the 2003 and 2009 versions) does recognize this family.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Lambstail"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Lanaria lanata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18874,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Paxillus cuprinus, commonly known as a type of mushroom, requires a moist environment to thrive. Although it doesn't need regular watering like plants, the surrounding environment should be kept humid. If cultivating this species, ensure the substrate is consistently moist but not waterlogged, to avoid decomposition of the medium. Spraying mist periodically can help maintain the required humidity levels. It is crucial not to over-water, as excessive moisture can lead to mold growth and spoilage of the mushroom crop."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Paxillus cuprinus mushrooms generally do not require sunlight for growth as they rely on decaying organic matter. Instead of direct sunlight, these mushrooms thrive in dim, indirect light conditions. If growing indoors or in controlled environments, fluorescent or LED lights can mimic the low-light conditions found naturally. It's essential to avoid prolonged exposure to strong, direct sunlight or high heat, as these can dry out the substrate and harm the growth of the mushrooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable to mushrooms like Paxillus cuprinus because they do not have branches or leaves that need trimming. However, for cultivation, it's important to remove any visibly contaminated or spoiled parts immediately to prevent the spread of mold or disease. Regular observation is necessary to harvest at the right time and to ensure healthy growth of the remaining fungi. Proper handling includes using sanitized tools or hands to avoid introducing contaminants to the growth medium."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Coppery Pax","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Western Europe"],"other_name":["Coppery Pax"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Paxillus cuprinus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19865,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Reynoutria japonica, commonly known as Japanese knotweed, is a hardy plant that doesnât require frequent watering once established. It is highly adaptable, capable of withstanding drought conditions, but grows best with consistent moisture. When planting, ensure the soil remains moist but not waterlogged to promote healthy growth. As Japanese knotweed is invasive, keeping it well-contained is crucial, especially when providing water. Overwatering should be avoided to prevent making conditions ideal for its rampant spreading. During dry periods, check the soil to see if watering is necessary but typically, rainfall will suffice for established growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Japanese knotweed can tolerate a wide range of sunlight conditions but thrives best in full sun to partial shade. It is highly adaptable and can grow in shaded areas, which makes it quite invasive. For management and control, it's important to note that although it can survive in poor lighting, the growth will be less vigorous. When cultivating, placement in a location with a lot of direct sunlight will encourage rapid growth, but containment strategies should be in place. However, in sites where its growth needs to be controlled or limited, allowing more shade can potentially assist in managing its spread."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Japanese knotweed is crucial for its control and management, as it is an invasive species. Ideally, cutting back should occur regularly during the growing season to prevent it from spreading. Depriving it of sunlight via pruning can weaken the plant significantly over time by depleting its energy reserves. Ensure cuts are made close to the ground, and consider removing and disposing of the cut stems properly to prevent regrowth. Early summer, when itâs semi-grown, is a good time for a significant pruning session, followed by regular trims throughout summer and fall. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent the spread of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Japanese knotweed","description":"Reynoutria japonica, synonyms Fallopia japonica and Polygonum cuspidatum, is a large species of herbaceous perennial plant of the knotweed and buckwheat family Polygonaceae. It is commonly known as Asian knotweed or Japanese knotweed. It is native to East Asia in Japan, China and Korea. In North America and Europe, the species has successfully established itself in numerous habitats and is classified as an invasive species in several countries.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["Eastern Asia","Japan","China","Korea"],"other_name":["Japanese knotweed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Rhizome"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Reynoutria japonica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Clay","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18780,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Raoulia hookeri, commonly known as scabweed, is a drought-tolerant plant well-suited to arid conditions. It requires minimal watering once established. Water sparingly, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings. Overwatering may lead to root rot, which is a common issue for this plant. During prolonged dry periods, occasional watering is beneficial, but in general, natural rainfall should suffice. Ensure the plant has good drainage to avoid waterlogging. Reduce watering significantly during the winter months, when the plant is dormant, to mimic its natural growth cycle."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Raoulia hookeri thrives in full sun and requires a position that receives plenty of direct sunlight daily. This plant is naturally adapted to high-UV environments, so ensure it gets at least six hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth. In shaded or partially shaded areas, Raoulia hookeri may become leggy and will not form its characteristically dense mat. If grown indoors or in less ideal light conditions, supplement with a grow light to mimic sunlight. Remember that adequate sunlight is crucial for the plant to maintain its compact form and vibrant color."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Raoulia hookeri is generally not necessary since it grows as a sprawling mat. However, occasional trimming can help maintain its shape and encourage denser growth. If desired, prune back any leggy growth or dead parts after the main flowering season. Regular removal of debris and dead foliage keeps the plant healthy and prevents fungal diseases. Use clean, sharp scissors or small pruning shears to avoid damaging the plant. It's important to note that excessive pruning may stress the plant, so minimal, targeted pruning is recommended only to enhance its appearance or health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Scabweed mat daisy","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Grey-green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["Scabweed mat daisy"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Raoulia hookeri"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19374,"attracts":["Pollinators"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Euphorbia serpillifolia, also known as thyme-leaf spurge, requires moderate watering. It is crucial not to overwater, as this plant is drought-tolerant and prefers dry conditions over consistently moist soil. Water the plant thoroughly, letting the top inch of the soil dry out completely between waterings. During the growing season, you might need to water more frequently, but in the dormancy period, reduce watering significantly. Always check the soil moisture before watering to avoid waterlogging the roots, which can lead to root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Euphorbia serpillifolia thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, provide it with at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth and blooming. In very hot climates, a bit of afternoon shade is beneficial to prevent the leaves from scorching. If planted indoors or in a shaded garden area, ensure the plant still receives bright, indirect light for a good portion of the day. Insufficient light can lead to leggy growth, so adjust the plant's position to increase exposure if you notice it stretching toward the light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Euphorbia serpillifolia, although not mandatory, can enhance its appearance and control its spread. Prune in early spring to remove any dead or damaged stems and to shape the plant. Trim back any overly long or straggly growth to maintain its compact form. Wear gloves when pruning, as the sap can be irritating to the skin. Additionally, if the plant starts to look leggy, more substantial pruning might be necessary to encourage bushier growth. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19179,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Swietenia mahagoni, commonly known as the West Indian Mahogany, prefers consistent watering during its growing season but is quite drought-tolerant once established. Therefore, when choosing a planting site, prioritize open areas free from competing shade of taller structures or trees."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Swietenia mahagoni generally involves maintaining its shape and encouraging strong structure. Be cautious not to over-prune, as this can stress the tree, and always use clean, sharp tools to make smooth cuts."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"West Indian Mahogany","description":"Swietenia mahagoni, commonly known as the American Mahogany, Cuban Mahogany, Small-leaved Mahogany, and West Indian Mahogany, is a species of Swietenia native to southern Florida in the United States and islands in the Caribbean including the Bahamas, Cuba, Jamaica, Dominican Republic and Haiti . During extremely dry periods, increase watering or mist more frequently."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cyathophorum bulbosum prefers indirect, filtered light and can thrive in shaded environments. Maintaining stable lighting conditions helps keep the moss healthy and vibrant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cyathophorum bulbosum involves removing any dead or brown sections of the moss to encourage healthy growth and improve its appearance. If controlling this plant, consider minimizing ideal growing conditions for potential host plants, which include regular sunlight. Managing host plant density and canopy coverage can indirectly limit the broomrape's growth by reducing optimal growing conditions for its hosts."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Phelipanche ramosa generally does not require pruning since it is a parasitic plant and not grown intentionally. Pruning can be inappropriate unless trying to control its spread. In this context, removal of visible flowering stems before they set seed can help reduce its propagule pressure. It's crucial to carefully dispose of any parts removed to prevent seed dispersal. If infestations are severe in agricultural settings, integrated pest management strategies should be employed as pruning isn't typically effective against parasitic plants."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"hemp broomrape","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"High","origin":["Europe","Asia","Africa"],"other_name":["hemp broomrape"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Phelipanche ramosa"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19180,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Polygaloides paucifolia prefers evenly moist soil, so it is important to water it regularly without letting the soil become waterlogged. During the growing season, water when the top inch of soil feels dry, ensuring good drainage to prevent root rot. Reduce watering in the winter months when the plant is dormant. It's best to use room-temperature water to avoid shocking the plant. If possible, rainwater is preferred. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and reduce the frequency of watering. Ensure that the plant is in well-draining soil to maintain optimal moisture levels."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Polygaloides paucifolia thrives in partial to full shade conditions. It is naturally found in woodland settings and prefers dappled sunlight as experienced under a tree canopy. Too much direct sunlight can lead to leaf scorch and stress, while too little light can inhibit flowering. An ideal location is one where the plant receives filtered sunlight during the morning or late afternoon but is protected from the harsh midday sun. If growing indoors, placing the plant near a north or east-facing window can provide appropriate lighting conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Polygaloides paucifolia is minimal but can be beneficial for shape and health maintenance. It is recommended to remove any dead, damaged, or diseased foliage as soon as it is observed to encourage new growth and increase airflow. This plant seldom requires heavy pruning; simple trimming of the stem ends can encourage bushier growth if desired. Pruning is best performed in early spring before the growing season begins. Always use clean, sharp tools to make cuts to prevent infection and ensure a clean, precise cut."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"fringed polygala","description":"Polygala paucifolia, known as gaywings or fringed polygala, is a perennial plant of the family Polygalaceae.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["fringed polygala"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Polygaloides paucifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19675,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Elatostema lineolatum prefers consistently moist soil but does not tolerate waterlogged conditions. Therefore, water the plant regularly, allowing the topsoil to dry out slightly between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's essential to ensure the pot has adequate drainage. In low humidity environments, consider misting the plant occasionally or using a pebble tray to increase the ambient humidity around the plant. Adapt the watering schedule based on the season, watering more frequently in the growing season (spring and summer) and reducing during the dormant periods (fall and winter)."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Elatostema lineolatum thrives in bright, indirect light, making it suitable for locations with filtered sunlight. Direct sunlight should be avoided as it can scorch the leaves. If natural light is insufficient, the plant can also adapt to fluorescent lighting conditions commonly found in offices. A spot near a north or east-facing window usually provides an ideal light condition. If the plant starts stretching toward the light or its leaves lose their vibrant color, it might indicate insufficient light, necessitating repositioning to a brighter area. Regularly rotate the plant to ensure even growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Elatostema lineolatum is generally not required extensively, but light trimming can help maintain a tidy appearance and encourage bushier growth. Remove any dead or yellowing leaves to maintain plant health and aesthetics. Prune back any excessively long stems to promote a denser form and prevent legginess. The best time to prune is in the early spring before new growth begins, which allows the plant to recover and develop new shoots throughout the growing season. Always use sharp, clean scissors or pruning shears to prevent the spread of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Large lineolate Elatostema","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Asia","Pacific Islands"],"other_name":["Large lineolate Elatostema"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Elatostema lineolatum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19075,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Diplazium dilatatum, commonly known as dilated glade fern, prefers consistently moist soil, but it should be well-draining to prevent waterlogging. It's important to keep the soil evenly moist, especially during the growing season. Water the plant regularly to maintain moisture but reduce watering frequency during the dormant winter period. Ensure that the soil does not completely dry out, as this can stress the plant. If grown indoors, misting the plant occasionally can help maintain the humidity levels that ferns thrive in."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Diplazium dilatatum thrives in shaded to partially shaded environments. It naturally grows under forest canopies where it receives dappled sunlight or indirect light. While it can tolerate a few hours of direct morning sunlight, avoid exposing it to harsh afternoon sun, which can scorch the fronds. For indoor cultivation, place it in a location where it receives bright, indirect sunlight, such as near an east or north-facing window. If grown outdoors, consider planting it near larger plants or trees that provide adequate shade."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Diplazium dilatatum primarily involves removing dead or damaged fronds to help maintain its attractive appearance. This can be done at any time of the year as needed. In addition to removing unsightly fronds, pruning can help improve air circulation around the plant and encourage new growth. Cut back fronds at the base of the stem using clean, sharp scissors or pruners. Be cautious not to prune healthy fronds unnecessarily, as these are vital for the plant's photosynthesis and growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Widened Twin-sorus Fern","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Asia","Australia","Pacific Islands"],"other_name":["Widened Twin-sorus Fern"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Diplazium dilatatum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18782,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Rumex sagittatus prefers a moderate amount of water. It is essential to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. During the growing season, ensure that the plant receives regular watering to support its development. In warmer months, you might need to increase the frequency of watering to prevent the soil from drying out completely. However, reduce watering during the dormant winter months when the plant's growth slows down. Always allow the top inch of soil to dry out slightly between waterings to prevent root rot and other water-related issues."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rumex sagittatus thrives when it receives plenty of sunlight. It performs best in full sun to partial shade environments. Ideally, the plant should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day. However, in particularly hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can protect it from excessive heat and prevent the leaves from scorching. Ensuring the plant has adequate sunlight will support its robust growth and help to produce lush, vibrant foliage. If you're growing it indoors, place it near a south or west-facing window for optimal light exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rumex sagittatus is necessary to maintain its shape and promote healthy growth. Regularly remove any dead or damaged leaves to encourage the plant to focus energy on new growth. You can also cut back any overgrown stems to maintain a tidy appearance. Prune the plant in early spring to remove any growth that may have been damaged during winter and to stimulate new shoots. When pruning, use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to make clean cuts and avoid any potential disease spread."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Climbing dock","description":"Rumex sagittatus, synonym Acetosa sagittata, commonly known as turkey rhubarb or rambling dock or potato vine, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to southern Africa, which has become a weed in Australia and New Zealand.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Climbing dock"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Rumex sagittatus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
